review_body: They offer exceptional service. I visited the Lounge, the bar and also the main restaurant. Everything was tasty. Staff speak fluent English and they are friendly and helpful. It is by far the best Westin hotel I have ever visited. Hotel rooms were maintained well and the hotel was well managed. I would be returning when I visit Tokyo again.

I stay at this hotel often and cannot say enough good things about the employees, location and overall experience provided by the Westin Tokyo Hotel. Easy 8 min covered walk from Ebisu station, lots of places to eat nearby, and only min away by train to fun places like Shibuya, Shinjuku, and more. Especially want to thank them for refunding money on a reservation that I was unable to use due to the Covid19 virus epidemic. This was before Marriott changed the policy to allow such refunds. Definitely will be back once travel becomes possible again.

A group of us stayed here on our way to a ski trip in Hokkaido. Excellent service and staff and great food. Went to the fish market and Street Kart Akiba go carting (great things to do in Tokyo. Hotel is beautiful with a good location in Tokyo. Would definitely stay here again.

My wife and I stayed at the Westin Tokyo on the first leg of a round the world trip in February 2020. We paid for five nights in advance. I am a Bonvoy Gold Elite member. Unfortunately due to a weather delay in San Francisco we missed our connecting flight to Tokyo by 15 minutes. As soon as we learned we were going to delayed by a full day, I called the hotel and spoke to the night desk clerk. She couldn’t alter my reservation to change it to four nights and issue me a refund even though I was calling more than 24 hours before I would have arrived. She needed to consult with the day manager which is understandable. But since I was going to be in transit they told me to straighten things out when I arrived. When we finally arrived in Tokyo and we are checking in, the pleasant but inexperienced desk clerk asked me sign for an arrival date 24 hours in the past. they were charging me for five nights even though my arrival date was off by one day and we would only be staying 4 nights. When I asked the front desk clerk about this she seemed confused meaning that my check-in date had not been altered. Evidently no issue with my reservation been relayed to the front desk staff. We asked to speak to the manager who promptly came out to resolve the issue. He was aware of the issue but was reticent to issue a refund. However, to his credit, As a gold elite member he offered me hotel credit instead of a refund. This was OK since we were going to be there for four days and we’re going to eat in the restaurant and use spa services which would’ve eaten up the refund anyway. The hotel has a nice lobby. The rooms were large, nicely appointed with decent bathrooms. The rooms are like American sized hotel rooms rather than the typical small Tokyo hotel rooms that are described on Tripadvisor. In other news, be aware that any notations that you make in the Bonvoy app (as far as special requests go) get completely ignored so just make those requests when you get to the hotel. I’ve had this experience over and over again at hotels within the Bonvoy system. Also my experience with using your phone as your key never works either. I’m not sure if that’s just something unique to the nature of the reservations that I made or if it’s endemic to their entire reservation system since the change to Bonvoy system. The buffet at the Westin was OK, typical hotel faire and certainly not spectacular. I found that the bed (in my room at least) was rather hard. The linens were great as usual at the Westin but usually the heavenly bed experience is heavenly and this was ....not so much. The staff was uniformly pleasant although there was some degree of language barrier but for the most part everyone was able to communicate fairly well in English. I did stop by the concierge desk to ask about having my luggage transported from the hotel to Narita airport. The lead concierge did not know the answers to my questions which I thought was unusual given that luggage transport between hotels and airports is relatively common in Tokyo. However she was Conscientious about following up on my questions and getting me the answers. She actually wrote a letter with the answers to the questions and various options for getting from the hotel to the Narita airport. I thought it was nice that she went the extra mile to actually write the letter and include the pricing of the various options. However I thought that the answers that she came up with was a little unusually pricey: ¥67,000 for transporting my wife and myself and our bags from the Westin hotel to the Narita airport by private taxi transport. That’s US$610. Well I don’t mind paying for convenience but I don’t want to buy the equivalent of another plane ticket just to go from the hotel to the airport. We eventually opted for a taxi from our hotel to the Shinagawa station and then from Shinagawa to Narita airport using the Narita express train. Taxi was approximately ¥2000 (US$20) And two one-way tickets from Shinagawa station to Narita airport terminal two (international terminal) set us back about ¥3000for the Narita express train tickets and another ¥3000 for the standard fare that goes along with that. So be aware if you want to do that you need to buy two separate tickets —one for the standard fare from Shinagawa station to Narita airport and one for the reserve seats on the Narita express. I would advise buying those train tickets in advance so you are guaranteed your seats and know what time your train is departing. So total out-of-pocket for us to get five bags and two people from the Westin hotel in Tokyo to the Narita airport terminal two was approximately ¥8000 or $72 USD. The trip from the hotel to the station took approximately 20 minutes by taxi and the trip from the station to the airport on the train was rapid even though Narita is quite a distance out of the city, it took 1 hour and 20 minutes. With the transfer of the bags from the taxi to the train allow for an additional 15 minutes, so total transit time would run you about one hour and 50 minutes. Now you may ask why not just take the Ebisu station train which is nearer to the hotel. Because that is at least a brisk 15 minute walk and that’s with moving walkways. That is not something that you want to do with five or six bags in tow if you are time-limited to get to the airport. And you still have to get from Ebisu to Shinagawa station which is another several stops. So doing that waste 15 minutes to get to the train station, more minutes waiting for the train and then the transit to Shinagawa to catch the Narita express. Easier to just take a cab directly from the Hotel to Shinagawa, it saves time and effort for $20. We made the walk from the hotel to the Ebisu station multiple times per day. It got old pretty fast. we don’t mind walking, it just adds up at the end of the day when you’re already tired. All in all if I were to stay in Tokyo again I would choose a hotel closer to a train station than a 15 minute walk.

Stayed here on a trip with three of us (all female). Extremely safe, clean and beautiful hotel. We booked a suite with club lounge and the room did not disappoint. I am a titanium elite level traveler and this hotel definitely acknowledged the loyalty and provided excellent service. Our room had an amazing view of Tokyo. Jim Woodrow was a standout in all things service. He provided us with a converter, a luggage rack and a roll away. He gave us great recommendations for a local restaurant. Jim went over and above to make our stay fantastic! We were unaware of the covered access from the hotel until late in our stay and we heard about it from Jim. The breakfast included a large variety of choices, American and Japanese. It was an easy walk to the train stations. The only thing that could be improved is the food and service in the Club Lounge. Some of the food in the evening was old and stale and the choices were not good. There is access to the 22nd floor for complimentary drinks that were well crafted (for titanium level and maybe other levels?) that we really enjoyed. Would love to stay here again. Thank you Westin Tokyo for your excellence, you made our vacation a dream come true!

I was literally in this hotel for four hours to sleep but check in was easy, the location was great, and I really wish I could have spent more time! The room was fabulous with everything I needed as someone traveling for business. The staff spoke English perfectly, which was a relief to me after running into some issues on other legs of the trip.

Compared with the Marriot in Shinagawa, the rooms were very spacious, and since it is its own dedicated building, the entire first floor is well adorned and makes it easy to find where the check-in reception is.When we checked in, they had no more king-sized bed rooms available, and offered us a twin room (both twins were large queen sized beds) and free breakfast at the buffet for two. It was a pretty good deal.In the evening I went for a jog around the hotel, and when I got back, a staff member at the entrance noticed I had been running and handed me a face towel and bottle of water. It was a much-appreciated sentiment.In general the staff is very polite and pro-active in offering greetings and creating a welcoming atmosphere.

Stayed at hotel during new year after reading positive reviews on elite benefits. Usually a pretty easy going Titanium Elite, but found a stay a little disappointing, and 3 stars probably generous for the particular stay. 1) Location's not particularly convenient if arriving by train with luggage. Took Shinkansen from Kyoto, by the time I'm at Ebisu station, I realized it's going to be 10-15min walk. Decided to take a taxi from there but got in an awkward moment where I felt bad for the driver who was waiting at station for pick-up given its such a short ride. 2) Lounge access offered from 5:30-7:30, but main lounge had a waitlist so was recommended to a backup temporary lounge in the Emerald room - Fine. Got there, but was again ask to wait until a table is set up - Okay. Finally my wife and I got seated, we went to get food, and within 2 minutes, our table was mistakenly given away to another guest and we were ask to transfer to a different table - Really? If this was not already bad enough, we realized that the food ran out (see picture), and this was when we arrived smack in the middle of the evening snack period at 6:30pm. In the end, we just took two soda and left. 3) Learned our lesson the first time, arrived extra early for breakfast. Great decision because by the time we finished at around 7:30am, there was already a line of around two dozen peopleThe only credit I can give to the hotel is that at least the staff try to be polite, even though my problems are clearly not solved, and that the rooms are on the more spacious side for Tokyo.

We stayed here on Christmas Day/Night after spending a week in Okinawa and the outer islands.Stay was decent, which is disappointing since this is a Westin. As a gold elite with Marriott/SPG the service was lacking. It seemed as if the staff was either new or didn’t care as a lot of the questions we asked were met with either confusion or a simple “I don’t know”. Asking for directions to the subway or trying to book transportation to the airport was impossible with the front desk clerk. The room we were in, which was an upgraded room with a decent view of the Tokyo Tower, was in need of some TLC. Wallpaper coming off, roof had cracks in it, etc.All in all, a very average stay.

We are staying here for business purposes. And now business meetings with a dinner party. My guests are very happy to stay here. We all are enjoying the tasty food here. Here swimming pool view is very good.

Having recently stayed at a Marriott property in Delhi, India where my family and I experienced ‘the best hospitality’, we were very disappointed with the lack of service we experienced at The Terrace (restaurant) at Westin Tokyo. One specific restaurant server (Akimoto) did not appear to enjoy what he was doing and was the absolute worst. Truly a disappointing dining experience when there were other options nearby.

My wife and I and two daughters stayed for 4 nights over new years. The hotel is very nice (although slightly dated) and in a good location considering the nearest metro stop is a 10 minute walk (Ebisu station). The room we had was large, very clean and the views were excellent. I have to say we were disappointed with the executive lounge service and exclusivity during our stay. It was very rote and cold service e.g. we were asked our room number immediately each time we arrived even by the same hotel staff and having been there a few days already. Also, on one occasion we had to be ushered to a 4th floor banquet room due to overcrowding of the executive lounge on floor 17. Additionally, there was little to no food on several nights due to so many guest stampeding to the evening buffet when the food comes out. Overall it was satisfactory but disappointing at the same time.

Right smack in the middle between the Ebisu and Meguro stations (about a 10-15 minute walk to either), but Ebisu can be reached without walking outside which is handy. The hotel is well-appointed and our room was sizable, although crazy expensive like many places in Tokyo. We actually had a great view of Mount Fuji.

I booked the Westin for a 5 night stay in Tokyo and couldn’t be happier. Our room (quite large IMO) had a lovely view of Mt Fuji. We were offered breakfast in either the lobby, Japanese restaurant or lounge (ambassador status). The lobby buffet was incredible and we went every morning except once.Location convenient to subway, and super cute restaurants 5 min walk away.Only con- gym was quite small considering size of hotel and there weren’t enough machines around 8 AM.Highly recommend!

Stayed at Westin Tokyo 4 times in 2019. When you look at the property, it doesn’t seem to be the most modern, but you would soon realise that it is one of the older buildings and it doesn’t in anyway impact the service. I specifically choose the November visit for review as it was during the aught World Cup final weekend. Inspite of the busiest time of 2019, the hotel made sure that the experience matched with all my previous stays. Managing lounge or, even a request for a meeting room in the lounge, the service was seamless. Staff was as always ready to help as efficiently as they always can. Also, the hotel is situated centrally in a very nice and calm area around Eibisu Garden, which makes it accessible to business centres through the train or taxi. You also stay peacefully by being a bit away from the much busier centres of Shibuya or Ginza.

This property reminded me of several different Westins in one - meaning I see elements of many eras of Westin - some modern, some classic, some vintage. They work hard to make it luxurious, and the property reflects this aggregate philosophy - some modern touches with a classic feel. It is mostly successful.Staff was mostly helpful, but a bit stressed due to the capacity / business while I was there. The property was packed, and I don't blame them, altho I did expect them to be a bit more capable during a high-demand (peak) week (New Years).Beds are phenomenal and the King was quite large. There is a lounge on 17 with food, and they offer a continental meal there in the mornings ,as well as refreshments during the evenings. There are three other restaurants - French, America and Japanese. All of them have breakfast options. the French one has the best view on the 22nd floor.

I stayed here for six nights in early December. Over the past five years or so I've stayed at several US chain hotels in Tokyo. If used points and found this to be a good value. The standard rooms are good value - there's room for two chairs and a working desk, even if you are in a room with two beds.The hotel is conveniently located - about a kilometer from both the Ebisu and Meguro stations on the Yamanote line. The Ebisu station is connected by a moving covered walkway. There's a good-sized branch of the Mitsukoshi department store, a convenience store and drugstore within easy walking distance and a small grocery store in the basement of the Atre complex. There are many decent restaurants in the Ebisu Garden complex that have menus in English, but I'd recommend venturing across the street from the Ebisu Station, where there are higher quality, more authentic restaurants.As you'd expect, service is extremely good here. I prefer staying in this part of Tokyo, as opposed to Shinjuku or Nihonbashi, because it is more peaceful. This hotel is not convenient to Narita, but if you don't mind a longer bus ride I'd recommend staying here.
user_name:
gocats89
New York City, New York

review_body: We are in Japan for our honeymoon and enjoyed our stay at the Westin for the 2nd leg of the trip. Did not feel the service was exceptional or anything special (especially considering I am a long-time member) The decor is dated but room was spacious and had a great view! It’s the holidays so checking in took a while (mobile check-in did not work) There were a lot of kids and strollers. Position of the restaurant made the entrance feel very congested. We realized only later that there is an underground walkway to Ebisu station. Wish we knew that earlier on a rainy day!

We had a great stay and the service was excellent. In particular the front desk operator, Xiao Xiao Dai, went above and beyond in terms of looking after us. 5 star service from her and the team! Thank you so much for helping us out and making our stay so memorable.

We stayed 7 nights and was given a corner room. We arrived from Osaka and had to walk outside and uphill from the Ebisu station for about 10mins with luggage and a stroller which wasn't easy. Upon check-in the staff were super helpful and brought our luggage to our room while we went up first. They literally arrived 1 min after us with complimentary drinks! Room had a classic feel and was pretty big size for Japan.Room had a mini fridge and complimentary water which was helpful. The water was replenished daily!On our first day heading back to Ebisu station, one of the staff immediately asked if we were going to the station and provided a shortcut (that we didn't know about) from the hotel. So if you go to the B1 level of the hotel, there is a pathway that you can walk all the way from the hotel to Ebisu station completely covered! It takes about 10mins but on the way, you pass by shops, restaurants and they have moving walkways for most of it to make it even faster. This piece of advice completely changed our thoughts about the hotel because we were worried that we'd have to trek outside up and downhill every time to get to the station. This shortcut was a saviour for those rainy days. We also borrowed umbrellas from the hotel on the rainy days.

I would always remember this hotel for its elaborate Christmas decoration and how busy the hotel lobby was. Apparently during the weekend that I stayed, there were more than 10 weddings in the hotel! However, the bedrooms were a haven - spacious bed with good linen, variety of pillows, spacious work area and bathroom with long bath and a standing shower! Among all the hotels that I stayed in Japan, Westin is the only one that provided body lotion! The hotel is just 10 minutes walk to the Ebisu Station and this is a less hectic area in Tokyo. There are many eateries in this area. From the Ebisu Station, you can get to the Haneda airport with just one change. One thing that stands out in this property: the high level of service ranging from the front desk to the concierge team. Thank you Mr Daiki Takahashi, Mr Rifcy Muhamad and Ms Masami Okada for your help in making dining reservations as well as transport arrangements to the airport. You all at Westin Tokyo are the epitome of hospitality! If there is any possible snag: I called the housekeeping number three times before my call was finally answered!

The Westin Tokyo was perfect for our 7 night stay in Tokyo. As a Titanium Elite, I was impressed by the concierge staff, in particular Ai Watanabe, who were very helpful in making our stay as special as possible. I had planned on proposing to my then-girlfriend on this trip and hotel staff helped coordinate the special day. They were extremely helpful from the beginning to the very end of the trip. The hotel is classic luxury, and lived up to the Westin standard. The Ebisu station was a 10 minute walk underground and allowed us to get to pretty much anywhere in Tokyo direct. Breakfast options (3) were plentiful for elite members. We loved our stay here and hope to be back one day!

This was our first hotel in Japan. It took us awhile to figure out that breakfast was included in the room rental, which is fortunate because almost all the breakfast shops opened very late (even the bakery!). Buffet was substantial, including omelets cooked to order, dim sum, some pastries, fruits, etc.About a mile from main train station in town. Can also walk to Ebisu station largely underground, which is good for rollaboard suitcases.Gym was quite spacious and had a lot of cardio equipment. Not as well furnished with strength equipment. Could use a few more free weights
user_name:
Rich W
North Kingstown, Rhode Island

review_body: The Westin is a favoured hotel for my company due to its location to our Tokyo office. I’ve always like Ebisu as place to visit as I find it not as chaotic as other districts in Tokyo.Location wise, I would say The Westin is both great but potentially not so great. The positive is that if you’re landing at Haneda airport, The Westin is very quick and easy to get to. I took the train with one change to Ebisu station and I was at the hotel in just under 40 mins. The hotel is very close to Ebisu station JR lines (10 mins walk) and the Hibiya line metro. That being said, if your place of business is to the east or central part of Tokyo, it might take quite a lot of time in getting there.The main draw of this hotel is the space and charm. It has a very distinct living room welcoming decor about the hotel and even the rooms. This makes it a very comfortable place to stay and relax after work. The rooms were extremely spacious for a Tokyo hotel, with a good size bed, space to work and very large bathroom. The bed was comfy and the climate control was efficient to keep the room warm from the cold outside.I didn’t have much interaction with the staff but they were nice when I spoke with them. Breakfast was impressive, although do expect to wait if the hotel is busy.If you’re on business in the east/south of Tokyo or fancy somewhere that is less crowded then the main tourist areas of Tokyo, The Westin is the perfect place.

I really think this was our favorite hotel of all time! The staff were absolutely lovely. Every time we had an issue they were super helpful. It’s about a 8 minute walk to the local JR station - Ebisu but it’s all underground which is perfect because it rained while we were there. There are shops and restaurants nearby including an awesome 7/11 but you can also jump on the JR line and it’s two stops to Shibuya. The rooms were super comfortable and the decor is fun and generally over the top. The best part of all was the breakfast, they serve breakfast in many locations including in Mai which is a Japanese restraint on the 1st floor. The main breakfast floor is on the ground floor and has a dream selection of food; western and traditional Japanese. We had rice balls, miso soup, noodles, fruit juice, omelettes - all for breakfast. Wonderfully made. The lounge if you have access to it serves drinks and food every day around 5pm. Great hotel!

Just had another wonderful stay at this fantastic hotel was here with son and husband and left hubby behind to finish business trip. November is a magical time in Ebisu with all the beautiful lights.I was here in April with my son and had a wonderful trip then. The staff is simply fantastic. We absolutely love Mr. Miyazato in the Compass Rose bar. He consistently delivers excellent service and is a lovely person. Nami the concierge is a star. Our room was perfect. The hotel is incredibly well managed. So thank you whoever you are at the top!

We stayed 3 nights. Our suite had a magnificent view. Access to the area with free drinks and snacks. On weekends complimentary Japanese breakfast which we did not like too much. Close to public transportation and a shopping mall.

I have been staying at this hotel between 20-25 nights a year for the past 10 years. It is in a great location just a short 8 min walk (through the covered skywalk) from Ebisu station. There are lots of restaurants and places to enjoy nearby. The breakfast Buffett is delicious with lots to choose from and the lounge on the 17th floor has nice views of the Tokyo skyline. But the best thing about this hotel are the employees. In all the times I have stayed here I have never met anyone who was not friendly and really good at what they do. From the waiters in the buffet who remember my fondness for ice coffee to the people who work at the check in counters, they really make it feel like a second home. My only complaint:). I wish they could have better WiFI speeds.

The hotel rooms are beautiful as are the gardens that surround the hotel. The Ebisu station is very close, within walking distance and it is only two stops away from Shibuya. There are also many dining options nearby and of course 7-11.

Took a short cab ride from Haneda airport to our hotel. The doorman opened our door and welcomed us warmly and took care of our luggage. After a long flight, the greeting was much appreciated. We are a family of 5; consisting of my wife and 3 boys aged 12, 9 and 4. Entering the lobby, we were blown away by the grandeur. We do not know much Japanese, but all the staff were so helpful and accommodating. Our room seemed a bit dated, but it was spotless clean and fresh. The attention to detail and service was on another level. The selection for breakfast for Platinums and above were spectacular. Service throughout the hotel was above expectations. In my opinion this location was a perfect starting point for our many adventures in Tokyo. Only one train stop away from busy Shibuya. It's very quiet at the hotel yet so close to the action. The bottom floor walkway to the train station was a bonus, especially when it rained. Motorized walkways going to and from the station were greatly appreciated. The hotel was busy as the World cup of rugby event was going on. With the extra crowd, we were always felt welcomed and all the staff were kind and professional while controlling the extra bodies. We definitely want to come back soon!!

I’ve stayed at the Westin Tokyo several times and it has been one of my favorite Tokyo hotels. This is the first time I’ve stayed at the Westin since Starwood merged with Marriot and unfortunately there were some noticeable differences. The rooms were still great and we got a Tokyo Tower view which was spectacular. The lobby was decorated for Christmas in early November and also was magnificent. The location is about a 10 to 15 minute walk to the train station which gives you access to all of Tokyo and there are lots of great restaurants around the Ebisu station. All of this was still great but the service seemed to have changed. A lot of the top notch employees were gone and there were many at the concierge desk who were not helpful nor did they seem to care to be helpful. The outstanding concierge was Nami who went out of her way to help with directions. The first night at the lounge was so full for Cocktail Hour that there were no seats available. Platinum member or those paying for lounge service should get it. We tried the French restaurant for breakfast one morning and there was nobody to seat us. We ordered and waited 45 minutes and no breakfast ! Others were served but we never got our food so we left and went to the lobby breakfast buffet which was good but very crowded. Several of the servers and chefs at the breakfast buffet also were not very friendly. Things have changed at the Westin Tokyo and not for the better. Not sure I would stay here again.

Definitely one of the best Premium options in Tokyo. Rooms larger than most hotels in city, very well outfitted - public areas with quality and style. Not always found in Tokyo where rooms are smaller than usual and public areas missing something.

Wonderful hotel. Rooms are luxurious and the bar at the top has magnificent views across Tokyo. Easy access to Harajuku, Shibuya and Shinjuku and all the nightlife that has to offer. Not cheap by any means but you get what you pay for.

Lovely room which was well equipped. Nice and dark at night with comfy beds. Breakfast was restrictive enough for Western dinners. On our last couple of days breakfast buffet was like a mad scrum so not the most relaxing experiences. Use the gym a good bit. It’s a good gym that wasn’t busy. Might benefit from some extra equipment like a rowing machine. Towels and water were supplied. There was no swimming pool. Spa had limited offerings so did not get to experience it. Lobby areas are decent size with nice atmosphere. We had pre advised of early arrival time and were able to checkin at 10am. This was really appreciated. Hotel was built in the 1990s and feels dated in some areas, particularly bathrooms. Ebisu station is just under a kilometre away but most of the way is under a covered living walkway so makes it feel quite close to hotel. Nice high end shopping area beside hotel. Bar on top floor has great views so worth a visit.

We stayed in Westin Tokyo at Meguro for 3 days. Quite pleasant. The funny thing is being in Meguro the Meguro train station should be closer but we found that Ebisu station was closer. The lounge was very crowded and didn’t have much variety of food but we still enjoyed the our stay. Rooms were big and spacious and we could admire the beautiful view outside the window. Breakfast was delicious. They had big hall and variety of cuisines. There was a big garden as well. There was a passageway from Westin to Ebisu station directly which was quite convenient. Overall I recommend Westin Tokyo at Meguro.

The public areas are very nice but the rooms are nothing special. I had an executive room one grade up from the cheapest and it was like thousands of rooms all access America from any similar brand. Mega expensive for what it was at about £715 per night room and breakfast. I was there at a weekend so opted for the Japanese breakfast which was interesting. The normal buffet breakfast was better. It was a short walk to a railway station and easy to buy a ticket and get to the city centre and costs only 200 yen to Ginza, about £1.40.There are free cocktails and snacks from 5.30 - 7.30.

The Westin Loyalty Team is always wonderful and Westin Tokyo did not disappoint. Jim was professional, detail oriented and kind; Concierge Team Daiki and Nami were so friendly and helpful. Beautiful view from the cozy room, bathroom with a shower, tub and Japanese Heated/Washlet Toilet. Heavenly bed and double duvets!!Housekeeping was great. When we decided to skip for the day and left the Do Not Disturb on, they slipped a card under the door, and a voice mail was left at Reception. The walk to and from the train was about 7 minutes, however, most inside via a moving walkway, and on the JR Yamanote line, so it was great for getting around.With Marriott Bonvoy Elite status, our stay included complimentary breakfast in the Exec Lounge/at the Terrace Restaurant AND the Japanese (Mai) or French (Victor's) on the weekend. Loved our breakfast buffet experience at Mai Restaurant! Terrace Restaurant had both western and Asian options, all food was yummy. Elite Benefits included western and japanese/asian evening appetizers, desserts and drinks in the Exec Lounge; drinks at The Compass Rose on a high floor for the fantastic night view, or drinks with a relaxing ambience at The Bar, on the first floor. Lots of choices!Chatting with Yoku in the Executive Lounge was a highlight. We even got to see a beautiful day and night view of Mount Fuji, from one of the rooms in the Lounge.Jim, Daiki, Nami and Yoku will be fondly remembered!It's often the service that stands out for us, in addition to the hotel + amenities. Our only wish was a pool after a long day walking, otherwise definitely a 5 for service.Our first trip to Tokyo and Westin Tokyo was a fantastic stay!

I visited Tokyo for the first time and stayed at the Tokyo Westin. It was a great choice with a beautiful interior and service beyond expectation. The location was excellent and near a train station, which made getting around a breeze, and restaurants in an underground mall just across the street. The concierge was amazingly helpful in getting you places and making reservations for you. I was there when they typhoon hit, and the hotel worked very hard to accommodate everyone with safety warnings and service. You can't go wrong with this choice!!

We had a large twin room with a decent view. It’s a 10 minute walk to the Ebisu metro station on the yamanote line. There are also plenty of restaurants located close by. Breakfast was great. We had just arrived in Japan, and were truly impressed by the hospitality and service orientation of all staff- which continues to be our experience .

Stay away. Prices are ridiculously high. Portions are tiny, no minuscule is more accurate. Quality is low. An assortment of their BBQ was about $45 and the portion served would have fit in the palm of my hand with much room to spare. Service was very poor. Overall advice: stay away. The lobby bar has ridiculously high prices too but at least the food served there didn’t require a magnifying glass to find.

The Westin Tokyo is in the Ebisu area. It's not really near a train station but about less than a mile away. It is within walking distance but not with luggage. We arrived at Narita and took the train to Ebisu station and took a taxi to the hotel since we had 4 pieces of luggage. This is a 5 star hotel in nice and quiet neighborhood. It is away from the hustle and bustle of areas like Shinjuku but the access to it is not very hard. The staff and service is exceptional. There are buses that goes from the hotel to both airports but you have to book it, The breakfast options is a buffet but the western options at breakfast is pretty limited but then again you are in Japan. There is a Burger King across the street in the building complex. Very nice hotel in a quiet location off the lights of Tokyo,

In Japan recently to pay respects to two Japanese families (long-term, dear friends) who recently lost family members. The Westin was in a great location to walk to the JR train station and to the subway. The executive lounge had good service and tasty food for breakfast and early evening snacks. The view from the lounge is beautiful. Ate at the hotel's Japanese restaurant and at Victor's, the hotel's French restaurant -- both were excellent! The food in the first floor restaurant was less palatable -- wouldn't recommend that restaurant. My executive-level room was well-appointed, very quiet and had every amenity possible. The bathroom was superb! The hotel spa and custom-level massage were great and very relaxing.

I have previously stayed at the Tokyo Westin and it is a 5* hotel. It is an excellent location, walking distance to trains, and is attached to a large complex which has restaurants, a supermarket and bars as well as shaded outdoor space. The rooms are very spacious (except cramped corner rooms), and the decorations are more western then they are Japanese. The rooms need a renovation however are extremely functional. It is a fully staffed hotel and they really try to help as best they can. So why only 3*? Our check in took almost thirty minutes and the lady who checked us in was a poor communicator. So we stood there as she clicked and typed and went back and forth on her screen without a word from her. Finally I asked if everything was ok, she said "Yes" and then we waited another 5 minutes. Finally she got it all together and we received our roomkey. Less then 4 words were spoken. Not a comfortable situation nor a nice welcoming check in experience. This is the face of the Hotel, IMHO and they must communicate. Lastly, our room came with Breakfast and the first morning it took 40 minutes to get 3 cups of coffee. Second day it took 30 minutes. They were extremely short staffed in their buffet/main restaurant. We were not the only ones upset, an AU man yelled at the manager "Why am I waiting 30 minutes for one damn cup of coffee????" Absolutely terrible service, not becoming of a 5* or even a 2* hotel. They had people lined up outside to get in, some waiting 20 minutes and they couldn't get a cup of coffee to the table in under 30. This was our experience for 4 days. So my suggestion would be to allow yourself time if you are planning to go to work as the waits are quite terrible and unacceptable. Overall the location and larger room size is what brought me back. That said, the mess which breakfast was has us thinking to try another property in Tokyo on our next go round. Overall a good property but this stay was surely not great. Travel safe!

The Westin Tokyo is a grand hotel, with good sized rooms that are well appointed, and beautiful dining options. The hotel is also a handy two stops from Shinbuya. In terms of the other important items - great showers, comfy beds and very clean throughout the hotel. Also consider an executive room that then gives you free access for the 17th floor bar and viewing area.

The bed alone is why this hotel gets 3 stars, along with the staff. Although the people of Japan are really 5 stars. They work hard to care for their guests. The hotel has removed a lot of key amenities, for example, the 22nd floor Compass Bar is now a craft cocktail bar and it is NOT great. Their use of paper straws disgusts me too. The straws wilt and disintegrate. Use metal stirring sticks like the Park Hyatt and the Grand Hyatt. This use-to-be a true, luxury lounge with amazing views and tremendous mixed drinks, with REAL Japanese mixologists who cut their own ice, and meticulously crafted your beverage. It’s barely acceptable now, and with the push to homogenize and politically-wash the planet, the Westin has stopped allowing cigar smoking in the Compass Rose Bar, which sat empty most nights. This is just sad. They have now relegated their luxury cigar smokers to a 12’x12’ “closet” with no windows. #SadSpaceThe SPG Lounge on the 17th Floor is well below international standards of quality for Marriott properties. We spent 4 days at the Sheraton in Yokohama and the Westin was well below the quality of a Sheraton? The Sheraton food and beverage trumped the Westin badly. Their Luke-warm tap water tasted awful, the breakfast lacked selection and was not rotated often making the food look old and unappetizing. Overall, the buffet breakfast in the lobby, while offering a tremendous selection, the quality there and the age of the food also made it unappetizing. It was not a great experience. As a Lifetime Titanium guest, I am sad to say this hotel has seen better days. I likely won’t be back again any time soon.

This was my second time at the Westin for a business meeting and both times I was very impressed with the service. One of the staff even remembered how much I plundered the ice bucket at a 2 day meeting 5 months ago and as soon as he saw me enter a meeting room this time, came up and asked if I would like ice! (And then kept me well stocked for my current 2 day meeting). Rooms are nice, with typical set up for a slightly older western- style hotel in some parts of Asia: vanity in the bedroom, two full beds, separate tub and shower.

Fantastic property. Service was top notch. Executive lounge very nice. The location in Ebisu is situated near a large metro/train station and has restaurants and some other attractions within walking distance, but at the same time is quite and upscale neighborhood.

Great hotel, rooms are good. Executive lounge is great. Good selection in the morning. In the afternoon is a hassle since there is not enough space. The walk to the metro is 15 minutes. The restaurants on site are great. Location is good and secure
user_name:
Alejotravelreviews
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: First time at this hotel and overall comment is “excellent”Outstanding service, facilities, upkeep, location, comfortable rooms. Food is good and plenty of others choices near by. Metro few minutes walking distance and 10 minutes rude to Tokyo central. Executive lounge can get crowded and lack of seating at peak hours. Only improvement I can recommend to hotel is improving WIFI speed and bandwidth. During high demand it can get agonizing slow (0.6 mbps)

I would highly recommend the Westin Tokyo. Takeshi Mitsukura, the front office manager, did a wonderful job welcoming us, ensuring we had the best room available and checking in to ensure we’re enjoying our stay. He made our stay very special!!! In addition, the hotel is perfectly located above the Ebisu station so it was very easy to get around Tokyo. The Westin is our hotel for every trip!!

Helps to be a Titanium Elite member but I knew the stay would be special because the staff started helping by email a week in advance with helpful commute suggestions and booking a couple of tours. The Exec Lounge is generous and has a great view overlooking Ebisu Garden Place. The breakfast buffet sets you up for the day. Very friendly service. The welcome Yamazaki single malt was the cherry on top. My wife and I had a very pleasant stay. Thanks!

I was here at a conference for 4 days. The meeting rooms were freezing and uninspiring. The hotel rooms were carpeted and need updates. However, the bed was very comfortable and a room a good size. The executive lounge was often overcrowded, I was asked to wait one evening until people cleared out. I felt discriminated against by being there by myself. I think they should have more single-person places or even allow communal seating. The lounge staff were rather aloof. The food and drinks selection were good, but food turnover was quick because it appeared that many people there were using this opportunity as a huge dinner. I could not believe the number of plates at some tables. Overall the hotel is fine for business but I do not see myself returning for a vacation there.

People are really nice at Westin Tokyo.Specially 2 server at the lounge on 17th floor Saki and Hiyori.I told her that I eat only halal food and she arranged everything for me.Overall service were A+......Thanks

This was my first time in around five years that I came back to the Westin Tokyo, and this time did not disappoint either. The room was very large but was carpeted and had an older feel to it, still very elegant in my opinion. The location is convenient, just a few stops away from major sights like Harajuku, Shibuya and Shinjuku. The JR subway is connected to the hotel, so you just walk around ten minutes to get into the Ebisu train station.The Executive Lounge is one of my favorites in the world - with a great view of Tokyo and a huge selection of breakfast offerings + afternoon tea.

We booked this hotel on points and for some reason were upgraded to the Imperial Suite on the 21st floor. This is the nicest suite in the hotel and is quite impressive. So our experience may not be typical. But the hotel is very nice throughout, including the common areas. The service is excellent. There are several restaurants, though most are quite expensive. As an alternative, the concierge lounge on the 17th floor has a pretty good breakfast. It is open all day, so you can grab some drinks or munchies in the afternoon and the appetizer bar in the evening is pretty good too. Alcohol is free and unlimited, but it served only from 5:30 - 7:30. Lounge access also allows you to drink for free at the lobby bar or the bar on the 22nd floor, but only during these hours. This hotel caters to weddings, so you are likely to have some wedding parties about. There is a shopping area with a few restaurants across the street, but other than that, there is nothing much in walking distance. It's a short train ride to Shibuya. The Ebisu station is a 5-10 minute walk. Taxis are also available 24/7 at the hotel. It's a quiet area at night, good for sleeping. Treat yourself to this hotel--it's a bargain at this price in Tokyo.

We arrived at The Westin at the start of our 2 week trip around Japan. Our room wasn’t ready when we arrived at 0900 but they kindly gave us a different room to rest in whilst ours was made up. The location was excellent in the quieter but central Ebisu region of Tokyo. I thoroughly recommend this hotel. We loved it.

Having never been to Tokyo, when mapping the hotel's location I was a bit concerned. However, I should not have been. Access to the hotel via the JR Rail Line as well as the Tokyo Subway is just a brief stroll through Yebisu Garden Place and a short walk/ride on a covered moving sidewalk. We followed the hotel's recommendation to take the Friendly Bus from Narita airport and it was an excellent suggestion which delivered us and our luggage to the hotel's front door. The hotel itself is beautiful, with a magnificent lobby area and fresh flowers throughout. Our room (1618) had a lovely view over the city and was large and inviting with a very comfortable bed. As Titanium members we had access to the Concierge Lounge, as well as flexibility on where to have our daily breakfast -- our favorite being the excellent dining room on the lobby level (our other options being the French restaurant on the top floor, the Concierge Lounge or on weekends, the traditional Japanese restaurant). If there is any room for improvement in the hotel and its service, it might be in the Concierge Lounge which can get a bit hectic, and food replaced very slowly, when the lounge gets very busy.Oh, and weather permitting, do take a leisurely stroll through the hotel's garden.
user_name:
Linda K
Port Saint Lucie, Florida

review_body: This area, Ebisu, is a nice area to stay in. It’s quiet but still accessible to the major neighborhoods of Tokyo (it’s one train stop or 10 minute cab ride from Shibuya). The accommodations are lovely, and what you would expect from a Westin in any major city. The international breakfast buffet is very good and the club lounge has a wide selection. The Compass Rose bar has good views of the city but is smoky. Staff are friendly and accommodating. Easy to get a taxi from here. Would definitely stay here again.

If you're looking for action, look elsewhere like Shibuya, Roppongi, or Akihabara.But if you're looking for a tranquil place that isn't in a crowded part of town, then this is the place for you.You can spend some time across the street at the Ebisu Garden place, spend money at Mitsukoshi department store, or just relax in the tranquil garden. If you want to go where the action is, you'll have to take the 10 minute walk through covered walkways to the Yebisu station to find something more lively.

Stayed three nights in summer when arriving in Tokyo. Hotel front and lobby looks amazing and very cool with the weddings during weekends.However, the price is high and We had a number of interactions with staff (Both service staff, restaurant Staff and the concierge) that left us a little disappointed.So all in all, a fancy hotel but We Felt that the price left something more to be expected.Rooms was large with Nice bathroom but slightly old-fashioned for our taste.Breakfast buffé at the terrace was really great though. Best part of the stay :)

This is my 2nd time staying at this hotel. Excellent business hotel with large clean room and fantastic customers services and my experiences from checking in to the day that I checked out was simply perfect. This time, I was lucky to be given a high 16th level that faced the city. Feedback from my wife whom accompanied me on this business trip were great too. The sheltered walkway from hotel to Ebisu station helped a lot as it was raining for past few days.

Summary: Will not come back because Tokyo has many better hotels for that price range. Receptionists need more training and be more professional, good Compass Rose bar on top floor, no swimming poor here, decent gym, old but well maintained room. Room sound proof is poor, you can easily here footstep above you. Taxi from this hotel to Haneda is about 30mins, costs about 7500-8000 JPY. I don’t see why tourists want to stay here.I only stayed 3 nights but I had 4 issues here. First issue I had was the Marriott Elite check-in line was not attended. When a staff saw me lining up there, she ignored me. I approached her and she told me there was only one regular line. She could at least tell me that instead of ignoring me. I waited for 10 mins to check-in. Then a nice gentleman (forgot his name but he’s the only Japanese staff member at the time) checked me in and apologized for the delay and unattended Marriott member line.Second issue, I told them to combine my two separate bookings in advance but they did not do it properly. They could not find my second booking for a while. Third issue, the guests above my room was partying. They said they could not do much other than moving me to another room. So I lost my Tokyo tower view room and the staff said I was upgraded to the Tokyo tower view in the first place and pretty much I should not complain about a room without one. I was pretty upset at that point and then she waved my breakfast charge during my stay. Fourth issue, as expected, I was billed for the breakfast and spent good 5+ minutes for the staff to correct the bill. When I approached the staff, she insisted nothing was wrong until another came to sort it out. The manager could only apologize and acknowledged that he often got complaints by Marriott elite members for not being valued in Westin Tokyo.As for the hotel and the room, it is decent, a bit old but well maintained. For almost $400 a night, I will stay somewhere else in Tokyo next time with Japanese hospitality. The location itself is not super great if you do not have business in Ebisu or Meguro. I definitely do not see why tourists want to stay here. Breakfast was ordinary and I don’t think it is worth the money if it is not part of your room package. I had way better buffet breakfast in cheaper Japanese hotels. The gym was decent but did not have many equipments such bench press with barbell nor smith machine. No swimming pool here. I do like the Compass Rose bar in the top floor, classy and nice cocktail. No cover charge as far as I know, hotel guest or not. Westin and Marriott continue to disappoint. I will likely stick to Hilton chain going forward.

I was facilitating a conference for over 100 people.During this time the level of service we enjoyed was fantastic, from the moment I checked in, to my departure. The bedroom was clean, well appointed and very spacious. The conference room itself was just as expected. All the team looking after us we very attentive, and I would like to make a special mention about Urpul ( I think that's the correct spelling) everything he did was done with a genuine warm smile, he came into the room at lunchtime on the first day and noticed I was not taking lunch, and was concerned by this. He was insistent that I ate something as he said " to keep my energy up" so promptly disappeared to get the bananas that I requested. He remembered how I took my coffee after the first break . One of my colleagues commented on the fact that it made him smile when greeted by Urpul each day . It's really great to be looked after by people that care, well done

First time here. Arrived and doormen were great, check-in perfunctory. Lobby and room oldish and need to catch up with the times. It’s wimbledon season and thankfully they have a local channel for thatGym was newly renovated and modern. Sauna only opens 9am-9pm and costs 3,000Y. Japanese restaurant mai was goodI took taxis everywhere but noted proximity to ebisu/yebisu garden place, which was good for starbucks and pharmacy

This is a lovely hotel and in a nice quiet part of the city. It’s close to the station and you can walk to Shibuya. There’s plenty of shops and places to eat close by but the food in the hotel is excellent. Staff are of course super helpful and polite. It’s a great base for whatever you want to do in the city!!

Situated in quiet Ebisu, this is a relaxing place to stay. The station is a short walk away and plenty of cabs available at the hotel or nearby. Staff are friendly and diligent. Rooms are nice and spacious. Conference rooms good and the whole hotel doesn’t have that cluttered feel you sometimes get. Pricey but worth it. The only disappointment is our room had that lingering smell of smoke which is a bit off putting

Spent 3 days @Westin Tokyo on a transit back from LAX. Pretty nice hotel located at Ebisu area. The surrounding place is clean, quiet and has a Ebisu Garden nearby! Around the area they do have many restaurants and fast food. One con is you have to walk quite a distance to get to Ebisu station but it is still manageable.Was upgraded to the suite room but I do feel the room needs a bit touch-up as some of the furniture and design is somehow outdated. Still, the suite is spacious and clean! The hotel has a few great restaurants and still affordable. Limousine bus is also accessible at the hotel for your convenience to get to and fro Narita airport! I love the club lounge and the breakfast, afternoon tea and evening cocktail spread is still ok. Staff are also very polite and accommodating.Great hotel to recommend for short stay I. Tokyo or business stay!Dr E. Chow

Stayed at the Westin for a couple of nights great location near Ebisu train station and other public transportation . Good restaurants nearby as well as in hotel. Had a great breakfast at hotel great selection for different palettes. Good service.

Over the space of 5 years, I've stayed in the Westin, Tokyo 3 times -- each time for multiple nights. Some quick observations:1) The hotel has a very nice location -- it's about 10 minutes walk from the Ebisu station on the Yamanote line. The good thing about it is that the entire walk can be done in doors (it's a little maze-y the first time you do it, but it can be done.). If you don't know what the Yamanote line is, it's the JR "belt" around the city, and the easiest way to get to most places. Anyway, proximity to the line is great. There's shopping and restaurants within easy walking distance. If the train scene isn't for you, there's a near continuous line of taxis (and of course, the hotel will be happy to arrange a black car service.)2) The food at the restaurants is very, very good. Local Japanese friends know the Westin mainly for the buffet - which they very much enjoy. The breakfast is really epic, featuring western favorites and Japanese favorites. Being able to pair an omelet with rice and a wide assortment of fruit juices is a great way to start your morning. The upstairs Japanese steakhouse is great - but very expensive. The hotel has 3 or 4 other themed restaurants, but I've not eaten in any of them, so it wouldn't be fair to review.3) Staff is very freindly and helpful. I've had help with local attractions, travel, and currency exchange, and it's all been very friendly, and very professional.4) Rooms are very good. They're average size to an American, meaning that they're larger than what you'd get in a typical EU or Japanese hotel. Net: Great hotel in a very nice location with fantastic staff. Hope you get to experience Tokyo from the Westin, Ebisu!

With a lot of choices in Tokyo one would think that a Westin level hotel would provide a better experience. From the check in (Titanium level member) to check out the front desk service was not very welcoming. The facilities are clean and premium but the rooms are fairly standard. The executive lounge was a disappointment. The lounge itself was basic and food was also basic. At over $500/night definitely much better choices in Tokyo.

Great hotel with very nice and attentive staff! I stayed in one of the suite rooms, and it had great views of the city! The Hotel is centrally located, with alot of shops, restaurants, and the ebisu station is only a five minute walk from the hotel. The breakfast downstairs and in the executive lounge are both very good and well worth the money.. Sadly, this Westin hotel is lacking in a swimming pool, and it would have been nice to have one, otherwise i would have given this a five star rating!

Stayed 5 nts & found this a good base to explore Tokyo. Located in a quieter suburb of TKY - the Ebisu or Meguro stations are 10 to 15 minutes stroll away. Easy to access rest of Tokyo from these stations & it was nice to return each day to a quieter & less frentic neigjbourhood. The Westin is large - many locals have their events & weddings here so there’s always a bustle in the lobby. The overall decor is grand in a 80’a vibe & does need a makeover to keep up with the times. However it is beautifully maintained & always scrupulously clean. Rooms are larger than average by Japanese standards and all the necessary mod cons for both business & leisure are there. They have nice robes as well as Japanese yukatas in the room & the Westin heavenly bed & linens are luxurious. Absolutely love the toilets with the warm seats & various water jets! The service is outstanding. Despite our early arrival (0930 hrs), they managed to allocate nice rooms for us (Platinum status does still work!). The staff are always gracious, helpful & so respectful. Many refuse to accept tips & it is such a nice change to see service that seems to come genuinely from the heart. The executive club is fine but a little small. Evening cocktail times tend to get very crowded & there are often no seats available. The food options tended to be the same every evening. Given they have so many F&B outlets in the hotel - perhaps more thought could be given to this area. Only rated this property 4 stars as there is no pool or the usual sauna/steam/Japanese bath facilities. They have a small gym & one has to pay ro use pool facilitiea at the Next door Yebisu Garden facility. For a hotel this size - they should have a pool. Overall had a nice stay but the lack of complimentary health club/pool facilities is unfortunately a deal breaker. Rooms on higher floors have amazing views!

Stayed here for a few nights and the location of the hotel is great. There is a nearly direct walk way from ebisu station (yamanote line) included in railpass to the hotel. Service was quick and efficient within the hotel but not always that attentive what we were used to in Japan. The room view was great but the room itself is outdated and does not par with the public areas in the hotel. Everything is well maintained but you smell and see the decor is from a different decade.

What an incredible staff and property. My previous visit was in 2005 but it’s hard to tell that the hotel is not brand new because everything is in perfect shape. The staff are all incredibly warm and not just polite. Didn’t get a chance to interact with the cleaning ladies but the reception, concierge and people at the door are genuinely nice. The room and bathroom were very spacious and in típ top shape. A pet peeve of mine is air conditioning, many nice hotels have loud AC units but at the Westin it’s perfect and it’s hard to tell if the unit is operating because it’s very quiet.

We spent five nights here earlier this month. The hotel is well placed for ebisu station and getting there from Haneda was easy. Although the hotel has a slightly dated feel everything is very well kept and the housekeeping superb. We had an executive room which was large by Tokyo standards. Breakfast was good and the executive lounge fine. Overall though the quality of the staff raises this review to five stars

This Westin Tokyo hotel is close to Ebisu station one train stop on the JR line from Shibuya away from the tourist bustle. Hotel provides excellent: hospitality. Staff are efficient and helpful. Our thanks goes out to Ohood Alamaw at the check in reception desk who did an excellent job checking us in and our son who joined us a week later to ensure we got rooms next to each other, When we wanted to buy bullet train tickets to Osaka the hotel staff wrote all the details in Japanese and we presented the list at JR Ebisu station office and was issued with tickets. The restaurants are excellent with wide choices of western and eastern breakfast buffet items. The in-house Chinese and Japanese restaurants . Lovely featured staircase in lobby popular hotel for weddings. Hotel was close to shops and restaurants. A very nice safe area. Luxury bedrooms and bathroom room well serviced. Two in-room safe units.Stayed during Cherry Blossom Season. Busy time but worth it. Wonderful experience.

Delightful stay at the Westin Tokyo! First, the staff is absolutely lovely and cannot do enough to make sure you have a pleasant stay. We had a beautiful one bedroom suite with great views of the skyline and park from all the windows. The main bathroom was large and excellently fitted with a separate tub and shower and every amenity one could need provided. The living room was nicely outfitted and helped us entertain some friends who met us for a drink. We enjoyed taking breakfast in the executive lounge on the 17th floor which is small and intimate. We found the location in Ebisu peaceful and a nice change from the bustle of other Tokyo locations. The Ebisu Garden Place across the street has many nice restaurants and stores, including a Joel Robuchon location. The Ebisu subway station is about a 10-15 minute walk but all by covered automated walkways. Finally, they made my birthday special by providing a nice bottle of sparkling wine and chocolates. A delightful 5 day stay.

All as it should be in this hotel: very good breakfast, helpful staff, nice bar and café in seating area adjacent to the reception. What stands out is the size of the rooms, huge by Japanese standards. Also very well appointed (though the minibar could be stocked a bit better).

We like the away from the city, did no mind the walking distance to train. Hotel was crowded during Xmas time. We ate at most of the restaurants in the hotel. Good recommendation, expect high prices for Japanese specialities compared to restaurants in other locations. Overall good stay.

We travelled to Tokyo via Dubai.We came to Japan for 6 days until we take the Silver Muse sailing this 13/05/19.We have found the service, staffs and room of this Westin Tokyo to be a a very high level.We will always make use of this hotel in future and recommend it to all our friends.Well done to the staffs who are incredibly friendly, helpful and vigilant.

Not much to fault with the The Westin. It is definitely a 5 star hotel with all the amenities. It's probably a little too old fashion lux for my likely however it has a lot of old world charm. The hotel itself is in upmarket Ebisu with many restaurants and shops near by. The train station is also fairly close. We decided to arrive at the hotel via JR and walk. It was probably a little to long to walk with luggage however we made it in the end. The rooms a very large and with nice views. If you want a really spectacular view, head to the bar on one of the top floors. Delicious cocktails, great service and a stunning outlook of Tokyo. My only negative would be the lack of security with the lifts. Anyone can access any floor of the hotel and can simply walk off the street. If you come into the hotel via the JR walkway, there are no hotel staff or security. When we were there, the hotel was extremely busy as it was Coming of Age Day. There were people everywhere for the ball that was on. Installing a key reader in each lift would assist this.

A Awesome hotel very well located for Philosophers Path, Nanzenji, Eikandji, KinKakuji.The staff is very very good always helpful and we got our own I will say Host who took us under her wing, advising us, helping my wife pick Vegetarian food options and absolutely we felt a personal connection forever leaving us with some real fond memories of Kyoto.So much so that we now want to go back again perhaps during Autumn and we are plotting routes to avoid another grueling 13 hour flight, maybe from Vancouver or better Alaska instead of flying nonstop from Dallas. Unfortunately the Japanese garden was not accessible due to construction..A lovely hotel, truly a great institution.

Convenient to subway/train in lovely quiet Ebisu plaza. Colleague complained shower head was too low, had to stoop, but I’m short so it was fine. Dry cleaning service was prompt, if a bit pricey, but I didn’t pay for it. Lobby is expansive, somewhat garish. Clean room, comfortable bed, typical 5-star experience with prices to match. Glad it wasn’t on my dime.

We have stayed at this wonderful Westin many times, as a family and as a couple. So the love of the location, breakfast and hotel itself goes without saying. This past trip was a 16th birthday celebration with my son - a mommy-son trip, hubby was left home. I was sporting a cane from a recent broken bone so having the helpful magnificent STAFF made the stay so much easier! Such a wonderful welcome from Lit Yee Shin. VERY helpful, kind, warm help we consistently got from Ai Watanabe. A lovely Aussie helped me with the bags and he is always great and helpful but I don't know his name. Before we even arrived the concierge team in advance and during the stay was top notch: Nami, Jun Kamimura, Daiki Takahashi. Mai Doyachi in rooms was very helpful making sure that we got the right room (two beds) Akemi ITO also very nice. Jim Woodrow and Rifcy Muhammad seem to act as hosts/customer relations. Rifcy on my last trip and on this trip in November was incredibly helpful especially this time because of my injury. Also helpful was some solo mommy 'down time' at the Compass Rose. The place feels like 'family' to me after all of our trips there: Mr. Taishi Miyazato and Mr.Takumi Kobari and Rina Kawaida are great. Mr. Miyazato and Mr. Kobari ALWAYS go out of their way to make the guests feel welcome and happy. The cocktails they create are works of art. Wish I drank more than just scotch on the rocks. ;) Mr. Miyazato and Mr. Kobari truly are highlights for me. Not only on this trip but in past trips with my husband who also loves them. Our room was fabulous with a view of Mt. Fuji. We can't wait to return...perhaps another November trip, this time with the whole family. BIG kudos to the General Manager! The Westin is a 'destination' for our family. Thank you for making it so.

The Westin Tokyo is located in Ebisu which is a quiet area, but only one train stop away from Shibuya. The rooms were large, clean and there was a lovely separate shower with strong water pressure. Our two kids (3 and 5 years) stayed free in existing bedding. Location was ok - about 10 min walk to the Ebisu station. Lucky the weather was nice and this made the walk easier. There is a lot of food and shopping at the station. On the other side of the station there are more cafes, restaurants and bars.Positives:Large bathroom with separate showerEnglish speaking staffSelection of pillows was greatNegatives:Location may be a negative as it is not directly next to a subway or train station, but as mentioned before, only a 10 min walk away.Overall it is definitely a 5 star hotel with spacious rooms compared to other Japanese hotels

It was my first stay at the Westin Tokyo although I travel to Japan from the US often. This time, I took my mother living in Japan to this hotel. They guided us to the lounge as soon as we arrived the front desk and they helped us check in as I am Platinum elite. We enjoyed drink and sweets until the room is ready:) The room is clean with a great Tokyo city view (Tokyo Tower) and the host came to our room to give a self-introduction and bring us sweets. It was unexpected hospitality and the services are greatly appreciated. They treated us as if we are so valued and my mother felt so impressed. We selected a Breakfast at French restaurant on the 22nd floor (I believe this selection is available on weekdays) It was a great experience as well. The hotel is located in Yebisu Garden Place. There are nice restaurants, museums, movie theaters and shops with a beautiful landscape. Easy access to Yebisu Garden Place from Yebisu Station via the Skywalk, an elevated moving walkway. If you need a relaxing time during your visit in Tokyo, this hotel is recommended.

I really enjoyed the location, the accommodation, and the staff at this hotel!Special mention goes to Ayaka who was working in the restaurant for their breakfast. She was very friendly, had a big smile on her face, and service was top rate! She is a big asset to this establishment.

Our family of four has been leaning AirBnB of late. Having a kitchen and multiple bedrooms for trips is a huge benefit. However, with our first trip to Asia, we wanted to have a hotel experience to ensure we could leverage an English speaking concierge and staff to help us with the language barrier. The Westin delivered in every way. First, the service. I emailed ahead and requested connecting rooms and was told it wasn't possible. However, upon arrival, we had been given connecting rooms which made everything better. The staff was incredibly helpful, well trained, and committed to impeccable service. From greetings at the front door, to the staff at the restaurants and lounges, everything was delivered with extra effort. I was in constant contact with the concierge via email asking for ideas and booking reservations. In one instance, they were able to get us a private room at a restaurant so our kids wouldn't be near cigarette smoke. Second, the amenities. The hotel rooms were nice but not extravagant. The lobby was very nicely appointed with a pianist playing some evenings. The garden outside was beautiful and the kids enjoyed exploring before and after our adventures in Tokyo. The lounge was great for a glass of wine or beer in the evening with an incredible view of Tokyo. Finally, the breakfast buffet. Oh the breakfast buffet. I'm Bonvoy Platinum so the breakfast was included. Western and Eastern foods. Curry. Dessert. You name it. It was the perfect start to our day and will be remembered for years to come. My only complaint is the Wi-Fi. It was slow, took ages to connect and would randomly drop calls. I was unable to take calls over Wi-Fi which meant either walking to Starbucks (not ideal) or paying for Cellular calls ($$$). Net net, we'd stay here again in a heartbeat.

It is hard to give a rating. We received excellent service at check-in and the rooms are very nice. The rooms are big, well maintained and appointed.The breakfast buffet was another story. The food is OK but given the price the food should be excellent. The service was a big problem. Once seated I was asked if I wanted coffee, I said later, please. The server never returned, no one cleared my plates, no one refilled water. Finally, I had to grab the waiter and order my espresso.Fifteen minutes later no coffee and just a stack of dirty dishes on my table. So I hunt down the waiter again and he says soon. Ten more minutes, still all the dirty plates are on my table and no waiter and no esspresso..... I give up and on the way I out I complain, Not even an I am sorry, they did make my espresso in two minutes and give it me in a to-go cup.Westin shame on for such horrible service at astronomic prices.

This is an expensive but very nice hotel in Ebisu, a quiet area of Tokyo, just a short walk to the JR and subway lines so easy to get around. The executive rooms are very luxurious and the executive lounge is nice although does get crowded. The breakfast and evening appetizer choices are not all that extensive. Have stayed in others, e.g., Sheraton Hong Kong, that offer more. We still decided to come here for a second stay, however, because the service is excellent.

This hotel has everything a jet-lagged international traveler world want to feel relaxed and refreshed for a business meeting. Convenient location for train access, big rooms, and solid food options. Will stay here again!

Just returned from wonderful Cherry Blossoms Tokyo. The Westin is excellent Hotel: in quiet and lovely neighborhood(Ebisu); 10-15min walk to Meguro River where Cherry Blossoms are magical in full bloom; Yebisu Gardens(square) with Department store, restaurants, bakery, coffee shops and Museum of photography practically next to the Hotel; 5min walk through this nice square to Ebisu Train Station where easy excess to Shinjuku, Shibuya neighborhoods. Hotel is very nice, large room with big bathroom, comfortable bed, great breakfast, wonderful staff, good service.Some reviewers said that this Hotel is pricey , YES it is, but all 5*Hotels are expensive. We would love to return and stay at Westin. Thank You!

Very disappointing. As a TitaniumElite member I did not get that special treatment that I was expecting. No upgrade, room view is poor situated on the mid floor. I understand that it is peak seson but at least make an extra effort to at least give me a better view and on a higher floor. And I told the hotel before arriving that this trip is for my niece’s graduation present and birthday. And what did i get when we arrived? A card with a tiny box of small face towel! Are you really serious Westin Tokyo management???? Not even a piece of a shabby cake or chocolate ? Is your service and hospitality this low???? And at the lounge, I could not find any bottled water. And when I asked the guy went to the storage room and gave me a couple. Really??? You hide those bottled water for your elite members????To the hotel manager - I think you have to re-train your staff on how to treat your elite members right. This is the first Marriot hotel that I was treated so poorly. So sad. And yes, you are no longer under SPG so you better remove that sign by the check in counters.

This Westin is well located in the Ebisu neighborhood, close to Shibuya, and adjacent to an upscale shopping and dining mall that includes two restaurants by Joel Robichon. The hotel is large and the service tends to the impersonal. I found more of a language barrier here than elsewhere we stayed in Japan. But I had heard that about Tokyo in general. While the hotel rooms are comfortable and have everything expected for a hotel in its class, Americans do not seem to be the target market here. I found the hotel public spaces - lobby and hallways - to be unnecessarily ostentatious, approaching vulgar. While the we had a good stay with no complaints, I cringed every time I had to cross through that lobby.

I stayed at the Westin in Tokyo for a night when I was passing through recently. It's expensive, but what hotel in Tokyo isn't? The rooms are large and well appointed, though not extremely modern feeling. The hotel does have some awesome decor though--incredibly cool carpets, elevators and furniture--this gives it a great feel. The location is convenient to get around, but not a ton happening right nearby, which is fine. Wifi is fast, fitness facilities are acceptable but definitely lacking--not an expansive fitness setup. Staff are perfectly friendly and do everything they can to make the stay pleasant. One downside, when I arrived, the room i had booked (king bed) wasn't available so they said they would put me in a room with "two king beds" (not the same thing!). The beds were actually just two smaller beds. Not what I had hoped for. I understand that things happen but for the prices you pay at a hotel like this, it's unacceptable.

Stayed here twice (couple of years ago) and having returned this time for business trip, the hotel was as lovely as before. The location is awesome (about 8 mins walk to Ebisu Station), all sheltered and the surroundings quiet, yet beautiful. We had the club floor (booked in advance so got a good rate) so the view was wonderful. The room has everything we need and very spacious! Size of the bathroom was fantastic too. You get both standing shower and a good bath tub. The restaurants served very good breakfast and on some nights when I chose to do in-room dining, the food didn't disappoint.Their location is also about 15mins walk to Daikanyama, a trendy neighbourhood with some good restaurants and the famous T-site Tsutaya bookstore. On the other side of Ebisu station you'll get traditional Japanese izakaya/restaurants. Above the station itself is a mall and there is a lot of pastry shops as well. It is nice after returning to Ebisu's calm and peaceful surroundings if you have spent a day in busy places like Shinjuku/Shibuya. This is definitely my top choice for hotel in Tokyo central area.

Enjoyed my six night stay at the Westin Tokyo when traveling to Tokyo for business. + Spacious room with an incredible view of the city including Tokyo Tower+ Very clean room with comfortable bed/pillows, nice amenities and ooh, the toilet :)+ Ample outlets and USB port for easy charging (I forgot my converter at home and the concierge was kind enough to lend me one for the duration of my stay)+ Concierge staff was very helpful and speaks English well, never had to wait for help+ Location - short walk to Ebisu station where you can catch the Yamanote line and easily get to Shibuya, Harajuku and other tourist sites+ Breakfast was excellent with a wide variety of English and Japanese foods (omelets were light & fluffy, banana smoothies refreshing and fruit delicious)- Loved the bar on the 22nd floor (the views were outstanding) but smoking was allowed and the smoke smell was so strong we had to leave. Drink prices very expensive.

I stayed at the Westin for five nights in a spacious room in which the decor was a little dated for my tastes.The room was located on the 8th floor, was clean and had the necessities in the room. A well stocked fridge also found within one of the pieces of furniture.The reason for the 3 star was nothing to do with the staff who were incredibly polite and helpful. It was based on the dated (in my opinion) decor and crazy high prices in the hotel bar £16.50 for a beer!!

It was my first trip to Tokyo, I was looking for hotel to stay for a long time trying to guess what location is best for a five nights stay. I selected Westin and I was happy to understand that the choice was the right one. I liked hotel, I loved area next to it called Garden Place with tins of restaurants, shops, cafes, bear places. One building looks like Paris, all signs in English, flowers all over.

It's my second time here while visiting Tokyo, and will stay here again in a heart beat. Location is awesome right off the a major train station in Ebisu. It's also walking distance to one of the renown cherry blossom spots in TokyoThe gym was great. Lounge serves high quality alcohol

We had a lovely time at the Westin. The room was clean and staff were very nice. One of the ladies was so nice and taught my daughters how to make origami. We are SPG members so we are able to access the lounge. My only complaint was the lounge. For breakfast we were able to use the upstairs lounge and the nicer one downstairs.
