However, since we were traveling with children they said if we used the downstairs one we would have to pay 20 dollars per child (my children are 8 and 5). I thought that was a bit ridiculous and unnecessary since my husband and I had the complimentary access. The hotel is a short walk to the train station and the Japanese restaurant inside the hotel was the best we had the whole trip!

Excellent location near Ebisu Station, 30 minutes to Haneda Airport, 30 minutes to Disneyland, super easy ride on Yamanote line to Shibuya. Rooms are nice and spacious, delightful in room amenities and very nice city views. We had the breakfast buffet every morning and it was totally worth it, a balanced mixture of foods including an omelet station and a sushi station.

I've stayed at the Westin Tokyo four times in the last two years for work. Overall, their service at the hotel is first rate. For a Tokyo hotel, the rooms are large but they are in desperate need of a renovation. What really makes this hotel stand out is their great lounge with incredible service and food. Once the hotel gets a room renovation, it is easily a five-star experience. I would stay at this hotel just for the lounge access.

I booked here as an spg member. The other option in my budget range was near the tokyo central station - but it looked small. When I travel for work I need space to spread out and work. The pictures looked like this could be it. Indeed, the room was good sized, clean and comfortable. The breakfast buffet was very good mix of west and east. Nothing to complain about - the only thing is: The location is a bit further away from everything. Its a good business hotel - but does require some transit time. I'd recommend. Oh - the toilet was worth the room rate!!
user_name:
MikeInTheAir
New York City, New York

review_body: First time I stayed at The Westin Hotel in Tokyo. Very polite and professional Staff, The Hotel has "A Touch of Class", from a beautiful entrance to excellent rooms, with the location only walking distance from Ebisu train station making it easy to reach all destinations in Tokyo. Excellent breakfast, rooms where cleaned to a high standard,the Conciergewas excellent in booking attractions everything you need from a high quality hotel.

I had a chance to stay here for about 5 days last month. Everything about this hotel is world class. This is a great hotel that had a lot to offer.Check in was easy and English was not a problem. They had a very international staff working at this hotel. I saw people from all over the world working here and they all had a great attitude. I was shown to my room which they upgraded. The room had all the amenities you would expect from a high class hotel. There was a king size bed, desk, sofa. The bathroom had a good amenity kit with a walk-in shower and bathtub.The room had a mini-bar and safe. The room was cleaned promptly each day. The staff even took the time to fold some clothes I had lying around the room. They provided a few bottles of water each day.The staff in the executive lounge was friendly too. Since I was platinum, I had access to the lounge and breakfast. I didn't use the lounge for happy hour, but once of the best things about breakfast was you had the choice of using the lounge or eating breakfast at the buffet breakfast in the 1st floor restaurant.One thing I didn't know until the last day was there was a covered walkway that led all the way from the hotel to the Ebisu train station. It was raining half the time and I got a little wet until I found this walkway.Location is good, it is one train stop from the Shibuya train station, which is the area with the famous cross walk in Tokyo.It was a great stay and would stay here again.

The Westin Hotel in Ebisu area, Tokyo, is an extremely elegant establishment. Seriously classy, situated in a chic area, it's certainly a good introduction for first-timers to Tokyo. Close to Ebisu station which itself has lots of restaurants and a nice shopping centre. We had left cash in the room safe by mistake and realised this only once we had long left Tokyo. The Duty Manager kept it for us until our return to Tokyo 10 days later; every cent was there. Impressive.

It was one of the worst experiences ever. The families got together to celebrate our grandmother’s birthday at the Westin Hotel Tokyo, and it was terrible. The staffs made mistakes on the reservation (inhospitable and not at all apologetic), were all very blunt and were extremely slow in doing anything. Things seemed disorganized (crowded and long lines everywhere). Above all, most staffs were unfriendly. I definitely think that it is not a place to spend a precious time together with your loved ones... We were just so disappointed and sad as it used to be my grandmother’s one of her favorite places... We TRULY REGRET bringing her on such a special day.

This is a beautiful hotel. If you are a Westerner and concerned about not speaking the language - you will be very comfortable here. There is a mix of Western and Asian travelers at the hotel. The hotel has everything you would expect a top-nitch Westin to have. This was my first time visiting Japan - and I was concerned about not knowing the language. This hotel is great and the lack of Japanese language skills wasn't a problem. This is a great hotel for business travelers - it is near our office - so I don't know if it is a good location for more of the tourist destinations.The restaurant in the lobby is great for breakfast and you can get traditional Western-type breakfast or traditional Japanese cuisine for breakfast. Something for everyone. Even for kids - the would definitely find something to eat - and it was delicious. This is a top notch hotel - especially for business travelers - in a very safe part of the city.
user_name:
Geoff H
New York City, New York

review_body: I travel to Tokyo often and always stay in this hotel. A short walk from Ebisu station, with lots of restaurants nearby, it is very convenient. If the weather is bad there is a way to get from station to hotel completely under cover. The views are beautiful and the rooms are nice as well. But the best thing about this hotel is that every single employee I have ever interacted with, from the people at the front desk to those who clean the rooms, all are friendly and helpful and make you feel welcome.

Yebisu Garden Place is a chic a shopping, restaurant, and entertainment community as you can expect and the Westin Hotel, adjoining it, is way elegant and comfortable. We R&R here, staying overnight and dining at the magnificent buffet in the lobby restaurant. The hotel staff here all provide high quality, friendly service. The wait staff at the lobby floor restaurant knew the wine we drink last night and brought it to the table to de-cork it just as we arrived.

This was our 4th trip to Tokyo, but our first stay at the Westin Tokyo. We usually prefer to stay in the Shinjuku area, however, decided to try a new area and I'm so glad we did! We travelled during the holidays so the lobby was beautifully decorated for Christmas. The service, as expected in Japan, was lovely. The accommodations were very comfortable and rooms fairly large for Tokyo. I especially loved the location which was just a short walk to the train station, but there is also a variety of shopping and restaurants near by, all within walking distance. We also had a beautiful view of the Tokyo Tower in the distance which was lit up at night. I would have given this a 5 review, HOWEVER, we did experience one minor incident. Upon check in we were offered a special rate for breakfast, but it was not explained to us that it would be charged immediately and no upon consumption. Upon realizing this the next day, we tried to resolve and had some what of an issue with the front desk until we asked to speak to a manager. This was not a language barrier as the staff we encountered spoke very good English. Thankfully this was resolved. But just a caution if you are offered the special breakfast rate upon check-in, you will be charged in advance, even if you decide one day to not have the breakfast at the hotel.

Upscale hotel with plenty of great dining options. Service is warm, welcoming. Close to shopping mall (in bad weather, there is an underground walkway) and to Ebisu station (again, also covered walkway in case of rain). Nice to be in an area of Tokyo that has a mixed feel to it (shopping, office, apartments, restaurants).

I stayed here for a week in Feb this year. It is a large property and well connected with metro and airport buses. The airport Limousine (bus) from Narita airport drops you right at the hotel. You can also ask the hotel staff to book the same bus to return to the airport. (There are no limousines for Hareda airport though).The rooms are spacious, unlike the tiny rooms you have heard about, in Tokyo. The staff is courteous and is comfortable speaking in English. There is a huge parking space outside. They don't offer free breakfast as a part of room booking so you need to book it separately, which I didn't like, given the price of the room. I booked the breakfast and found it to be quite good, with variety and taste. They have an Indian mixed veg and Paratha option in breakfast everyday which sorts out lots of issue for my vegetarian Indian friends.Ebisu metro station is around 1 km while Meguro station is 1.5 kms, both comfortably walkable. Both metro statsions lie on the Yamanote line which has some of the main stations -Shnjuku, Shibuya, Ueno Park on the circuit making it easy for you to travel to these paces. There is a high end mall right opposite the hotel, the Yebisu tower. There are lot premium restaurants there. I tried a couple of them and the food was amazing. Yebisu Beer museum is in the same mall complex.

Business people - do not stay here. This hotel is not for you.Westins are usually business hotels. A good internet connection is a fundamental requirement for business people.At best on all devices I was getting 500 kbps - these are connection speeds from 1995.The tech support was unable to help.They are throttling connections between hotel guests and saving money.

Unfortunately was only here for 2D1N for work and didn't get the chance to extend the stay. The staff was friendly. Although the hotel furnishing looks a little old, it is clean. The room was equipped with the necessary amenities. And the hotel is located near eateries and shopping areas (always a plus point!)

Last time stated here was 10 years ago. And I'm glad I choose this place for my wedding anniversary. I spent 1N at the hotel. Assigned a room on the 21st floor (second highest level). Nice views of Tokyo Tower, comfy bed, speedy wifi, good AC. As a plat, i was given full club privileges. I had access to the club lounge. Happy Hour however was chaotic on the weekend with lots of kids. I wad able to partake standard pour evening cocktails at the Compass Rose (on the top floor). Ate breakfast at Victor's (also on the top floor) ordering from a course menu. Ebisu subway is about a 10 minute brisk walk / travelator from the hotel via covered walkways. Nice neighbourhood with interesting restaurants. The best part of the stay was the surprise gift waiting for my wife... a chilled bottle of champagne! Will be back soon!

The Westin Tokyo must be one of the top properties in the Westin chain. The lobby and public areas are high-end. As a Marriott Platinum (after the SPG merger - before the BonVoy rebranding) staying 5 nites on points, we got upgraded to a corner king; it had a comfortable couch and armchair, and a desk, with plenty of room to move around and store clothing, etc. Staff was ultra-responsive, and almost everyone spoke enough English to be able to help us with what we needed (even if it was outside their direct responsibility). The location is great - an easy walk to Ebisu Station, which is both a Tokyo Metro and a JR station.

We booked 2 rooms for a family of 4...a wonderful stay. Upgraded to a city view room for my wife and I (including complimentary breakfast). Rooms were very clean and quiet. Thanks especially to Jim (Guest relations) for taking care of us. We found this to be in a better location to the Ritz and Hilton (where we also stayed).Shall be back.

I have stayed at this Westin a few times during my business trips. It is a little old and dated but clean, convenient, and staffed with friendly people. If you are an elite Starwood member they provide you with extra fancy things in your room upon your request like fancy bath soaps, fancy shampoo/conditioner (that smell really good!), and other stuff. They even supply disposable brushes in the room for your hair, which is the only time I have seen this but find them very convenient!The Starwood elite lounge is just OK but has nice views. The breakfast (on the lower floor) offered is huge with tons of vegetarian and vegan options. If you have a special dietary request, they will gladly accommodate and make you something special. My only gripe about the breakfast is that they consistently take forever to bring you tea. In fact, I am generally done with my breakfast and ready to go to my client's office by the time they bring the tea over. Sometimes I have to ask several times.This hotel is located in Ebisu near the Yaminote Line, which is 100% convenient. This line circles around the city and connects with several other lines. Shibuya and Shinjuku are also pretty close by train for the tourists.Again, this is a clean, convenient hotel with friendly staff. I would recommend the hotel and would stay again.

I have stayed here a couple of times during 2018 year end season. The rooms are spacious and welcoming. Staffs are friendly. Being an Indian, i found very less Indian food options for in-room dining and during breakfast. I didn't mind it though. Location is good, away from the crowd and about 7-8 mins walk from the Ebisu train station.

As SPG members, we've enjoyed domestic business and couples stays in Westin hotels in the past. But the level of Japanese hospitality we experienced at the Westin Tokyo was definitely beyond compare. The lobby, restaurants, and gardens exuded elegance and serenity. The high-floor executive room we requested had everything we asked for including a spectacular city view. The level of service was very impressive as well.At any given time there appeared to be at least three or four staff people available to provide assistance or answer questions in English or via efficient use of the Japanese toEnglish cell-phone translation app. Staff persons were always willing to 'take that extra step' to make visitors' stays more comfortable. For example Jim, the Bell Staff Captain, hand-wrote out every step for us to walk from the hotel to the busy train station and purchase tickets for a day trip. (I remain convinced that if he had time,he would have taken us by the hand and personally put us on the train!) Breakfasts were sumptuous, and service was friendly and efficient. The Westin location in Ebisu is lovelywith shops and restaurants in walking distance--and the Westin Tokyo hotel provided the perfect introduction for our first visit to Japan.

Everything you would expect of a Westin and a lot more. The location in Ebisu is perfect, a little out of the bustle but in a very nice and upcoming neighbourhood. Museums, stores and restaurants are close by and the subway a 10 minute enjoyable walk away. Service is top-notch. Spring for the executive level, as it will not only give you access to the executive lounge, but also to the other hotel restaurants for breakfast. Gym is nicely equipped and spacious. A nice 5K running course mapped out starting from the hotel.
user_name:
Alex D
San Miguel de Allende, Mexico

review_body: This hotel is spacious (what you pay is what you'll get). Rooms are decent size, and there are writing desk and a make up desk as well. My room had a view of Mt Fuji, only wish it was on a higher floor .Hotel staff that attended to me spoke good English ( not every one of them speak decent English). Check-in was fast ( Spg gold member)It's not near the station - easily 10 minutes walk ( my speed). However, there are cafes just opposite the hotel . There is also a big departmental store just before the station, Burger King is just opposite the departmental store. Once you are at the station, there are more restuarants located in the station. Some on L6 and some at the basement. In addition, if you walk out of the station ( East exit , not in the direction of Westin Hotel) , there are even more local restaurants- tons of them.

My wife and i stayed here for 5 nights in December 2018. The hotel is located in a nice and quiet upscale neighborhood of Tokyo (Ebisu) with easy access to the Metro. I would definitely stay here again whenever I return to Tokyo. Great platinum benefit with being able to have breakfast in any of the hotel restaurants or in the club lounge. Victor's restaurant on the top floor has fantastic 360 views of all of Tokyo. The rooms are well appointed as well but i think are due for modernizing refurbishment with regard to decor and furniture. Everything worked though and was well maintained. The bed is extremely comfortable! We also appreciated having a Bose Sounddock in the room for playing music.

We've stayed at the Tokyo Westin a number of times on business and family pleasure trips over the past three years. The decor is over the top French and not entirely to my liking to be honest (Hey, I'm American), but the Hotel is phenomenal. Location is not super handy for subway/trains but not too bad by cab and most Tokyo centers are no more than 12-15 minutes by cab. The 12 minute walk down to Ebisu Station is pleasant for day tripping or going out, but not with suitcases. Ebisu station area itself is a little neighborhood microcosm with the usual Karaoke, bars, fun little places and a good foreign grocery store I can't remember the name of (National Azabu?) but we find it easily. I'd love to spend more time exploring that little neighborhood. ip: great presents from Japan are candy, food items and things like Shiseido consumer shampoos which are very elegant. Value: breakfast is exceptional even by terrific Tokyo 'Viking' standards. Pay the extra on your room bill and eat well before you go out the door! Platinum Level: we have been very kindly upgraded on occasion allowing us to use the Club floor. We've entertained a number of key clients there and it's very good for business! View are phenomenal, service is JAL 1st class style and there are endless snacks and beverages. It is a business amenity I would recommend to literally anyone doing business in Tokyo for whatever reason. Take your people up there for a taste of the Tokyo night skyline and it's a deal closer! The Bar: we have found this cozy, expensive little room to be warm, welcoming and invariably meet somebody very interesting. We interviewed with a Trade News agency in the lobby, then celebrated the end of a successful business trip with a fine scotch at the bar. Memorable for me and my team. The Bartenders are world class Pros. Great ice. Tokyo Westin for business? Absolutely.

Have stayed at a few Tokyo hotels, and the Westin is so far the best. Located close to two stations, shopping and convenience stores. The decor and rooms feel luxurious and well cared for - other hotels are far more dated. The facilities are adequate - reasonable gym with plenty of options, lots of dining and friendly staff. Quiet, safe area, not too far to taxi from Haneda airport.

I had no idea where to book in TokyoEven though I did my research before hand, there were so many choicesHowever, the Westin Tokyo is in the very best location in my mind.It's at the Ebisu subway stop - which is between the north and south routes and points of interestFor example, the first day we travelled two stops to Harajuku subway station and visited the Meiji Temple and the Cat Street with anime characters- in one visitTalk about two different worlds!It also allowed us to go a few stops north to the JR booking office at Shingawa in one day and then travel south line to Shinagawa to catch the Shinkansin train to Kyoto (actually we stopped in Hamamatsu first to meet some friends- it's a cute city).I was very nervous to visit/stay in Tokyo as it's so big- but staying at The Westin Tokyo was a very fortunate stroke of luck- and the staff are fabulous.They will provide a subway map and help you with many directions and recommendations for sites and restaurants to visit.Can't say enough good about this hotel and this choice for our Tokyo stay.

Overall hotel was good with large rooms, great restaurant selections and great views on upper levels.Poor English with many staff, therefore many incidences of lost in translation, e.g. ordered 2 glasses of wine with room service, got 1 bottle, huge price difference, ordered Bloody Mary extra spicy at Bar/ Lounge and got a non alcoholic watered down tomato juice.Other areas that could do with some improvements: keep getting messages on room phone, but message service all in Japanese, therefore cannot retrieve messages. Booked restaurant for 1 evening via concierge but was not told no reservations available, turned up at restaurant and was told no availability.And why the non-smoking bars??!!! Both the Compass Rose and GF Bar are smoking, so if you don't like the smoke you can't enjoy a drink at any bar and the smoke travels into the non-smoking Lounge area. We sat just outside the Bar and left stinking like an old pipe! Awful!! Service was very slow as well, took 20 mins to get a glass of the wrong wine... ordered a rose and got a sparkling rose.I also agree security is an issue with access to floors and the hotel in general not secured... the Lobby is often filled with the general public taking photos of the Christmas decorations, makes exiting and entering the hotel a very unpleasant experience... oddest thing to see and gets ridiculous navigating around the crowd. Executive Lounge is also unusable at cocktail hour, with free access for everyone due to unsecured fllor, a bit uncontolled, unfortunately another unpleasant experience...Hope to come back when it's ready to be a true 5-star hotel.

Normally I would wait until completing a stay at a hotel before reviewing it; however, the Westin Tokyo service for platinum members at Victor's was so bad that it requires immediate comment. We went for a complementary breakfast. It was sitdown with one serving person and one more senior person. We had to wait about 15 minutes before our order was taken, another 10-15 minutes for a cup of coffee, then more time for orange juice, even more time for meusli. Finally after close to an hour of torture we got up to leave because we were fed up with waiting for our eggs, when the senior gentleman ran after us, because they were finally ready. There was no offer of additional coffee, no butter or jam with our bread. And quite frankly nothing but the orange juice tasted any good. This was disgraceful treatment.The room itself is great.

Very nice location, very nice service and amazing spacious rooms. Easy to get taxis. Easy access to metro station. Endless breakfast options... In case you a fan of long relaxing breakfasts. And relatively well priced

Overall, my 3 nights stay had been pleasant except for a hiccup on my 2nd night. After working late, my access card to my room failed and I had to walk down during late night to have it rectified. Reason given for the card issues was that I placed the card near my mobile phone, though the card was always in my jacket and my mobile phone in my pant pocket, well seperated. There is no apology from the lady at the reservations desk and she made it appeared that it was my fault. Sigh! Other than this unhappy incident, I must say that the room is large by Japanese hotel standard, all amenities provided and room is clean. Breakfast served at the lobby cafe is not too bad with good varieties and fresh fruits. Hotel is linked to covered path to rail station and shopping mall. Most of the employees at the hotel can understand English. An important area for improvement is the lacking of tight security as anyone can access the lift and every floor without a card access key, and not many security personnel around.

Writing another review. We were here in January (in a snow storm!) Back in November and enjoyed the beautiful fall leaves. The hotel is always excellent - this is our go to hotel in Tokyo. My husband often comes for work. We were happy with our stay in January (which was not work related...just 'because' and for his birthday) and loved our recent stay here in November. The management is still doing an EXCELLENT JOB. Love the location. Very festively decorated for Xmas. Great breakfast. The staff very kind and helpful. Worthy of mention: Mr. Taishi Miyazato manager of SKY LOUNGE Compass Rose is WONDERFUL and always makes us feel welcome. He remembered us from January as did the amazing and attentive Takumi Kobari Bartender and Whiskey Sommelier is fantastic.We had the pleasure of meeting Rina Kawaida. Captain of the Sky Lounge Compass Rose for the first time and she is a very good bartender. Before we arrived Jun Kamimura the concierge was VERY helpful making dinner reservations and helping with booking bus from Hotel to Airport. Aye Myat Mon Front Office Agent checked us in 11/24/18 and gave us a very welcoming check in. Met Mr. Rifcy Muhammad at check out who was gracious and helpful. Joshita helped with bags and was also very helpful and attentive. We hope that we will have the pleasure of returning in the near future.

I stayed in quite a few Westin/Marriotts and this one was a bit disappointing. The room was a bit old (design, carpet, washroom, etc). It's clean and tidy, which is good. It's too dark even after i turned on all the lights. The staff at the receptions and entrances were friendly, which is good. The price is considered as mid-range in Tokyo as many other 5 stars are very expensive at the time i stayed.The location was quiet. It's around 15 mins walk to the nearest station in Ebisu, so be prepared to have quite a bit of walking. I booked it along with the breakfast package. The breakfast was terrible. The food was ok and it's the typical Japanese standard, so it can't be too bad. It seems that they are always under staff. 2 out of 3 days my order of drinks either didn't come or need to ask for multiple times.

This is a beautiful hotel, with large rooms, multiple dining options, great service and a staff who speak excellent English.Check-in was quick. Rooms are very large by Japanese hotel standards with modern, traditional style furnishings, including small sofa and working desk. Bathroom is also large, with separate shower (rain shower and handle options) and soaking tub. Amenities include free bottle of water daily, mini-bar, bathrobes/slippers, in-room safe, plenty of bath products, and free wi-fi. Laundry was returned same day. There are several English language TV channels. Internet is fast.All employees with whom I interacted spoke excellent English and were very helpful and friendly. There are multiple restaurants (2 Japanese, 1 Chinese and a buffet). I ate both Japanese restaurants -- service and food were excellent, though prices are not cheap. As others have said, the hotel is located in a combo residential/commercial area 20-30 minutes by cab or subway from the center of the city. That said, the area is quiet and pleasant, with many dining options a short walk away. Two issues -- one major and one minor. The Westin Executive Lounge is a complete disaster in the evening. There is no access check of any kind. Anyone can access the floor and enter the lounge. No requirement for card key access and they don't even ask for your room number. As a result, the place is standing room only (literally) during the evening snacks/cocktail hour (5:30-7:30). The first night I arrived at 5:40. Had to wait/stand 20 minutes to get a seat. They were out of most dishes when I arrived; many of them (e.g., smoked salmon) were not replaced by the time I left at 7:00. Over the course of the 3 days, I learned that, if you wanted a seat, you had to arrive no later than 5:15 or wait 20 minutes. People started grabbing food at 5:15 even though service wasn't supposed to start until 5:30. Thus, they ran out of many items within 15-30 minutes and several were never replaced.Bottom line: Anyone from outside the hotel or inside the hotel can avail themselves of free food and drink and I suspect many of those in the lounge had not paid for the privilege (and might not even have been hotel guests). Some people took heaps of food, leaving none for other guests. The servers were super-friendly and did their best to keep up with demand, but it was not a pleasant experience and I was sorry I'd paid extra for it.Breakfast in the lounge, OTOH, was never crowded, no matter the time. The food was good, with both western and Japanese options. Eggs, meat, cheese, salad, breads, fruit, juice, cereal, miso soup, rice, etc. The other minor nit concerned a concierge dining reference. He sent me to a Japanese sushi restaurant (I love sushi). He'd given me only the English name but the signs were only in Japanese -- since there were about 10 restaurants in the immediate area, I had to guess which one was the right one. When I figured it out, I learned no one there spoke a word of English and the menus were only in Japanese. That's ok (it is Japan after all) but I'd specifically told the concierge that I wanted a place with some level of English since I don't speak/read Japanese. I ended up eating elsewhere.Overall, it was a good stay and -- if they fix the lounge issues -- would have been a great one. Definitely recommend it for US visitors, provided you are willing to commute downtown if you need to be there.

We really enjoyed this hotel. It was beautiful and our rooms were a nice size. (The "twin" rooms have what I'd call wide twin beds. Definitely only wide enough for one, unless you have small children.) We weren't sure about the location, but it was very easy to walk to the Ebisu train/subway station. There's even a way to walk the entire way to the station under ground -- just go to the B1 level of the hotel and follow the signs. The breakfast was what you would expect at a nice Western-owned hotel in Asia. A mix of Asian and Western food with your usual assortment. It truly tasted Western, which isn't always the case.

This elegant, beautiful hotel is in a quiet neighborhood with a lovely outdoor mall across the street and easy access from the JR Yamanote line. Take the train to the Eubisa station and use the east exit to Yeibusa Garden. If it's a nice day walk outside, look up and you can see the Westin. Or, take the people movers, 5 in all to end and follow the signs to the lower level entrance to the hotel, take the escalator to the main lobby that had an enormous Christmas tree and display. We found the staff to be wonderful, very hardworking. There's an elegant restaurant on the 22nd floor, with beautiful views of the city. The food was top notch. We didn't eat in the main floor buffet, it was always busy. We walked around the hotel, it's very residential, we didn't see any restaurants but there were several in the outdoor mall. Even a Burger King. We were able to use our JR rail pass to get to Narita. We took the JR Yamanote line to Shinagawa station, avoiding Tokyo station. The Narita Express was track 13, we had our reservations from an earlier visit to the JR office. We allowed 4 hours to get through travel, security, checking in and it was plenty.

Stayed for just 2 nights, but was a good quality business hotel. Didn’t get a chance to use the gym, but enjoyed a nice big room with decent views. Staff were very pleasant, Christmas decorations in the lobby were stunning and was pretty good all in all. Bit far from the centre for me, though, but think the price reflects that.

I have stayed in the hotel 8-10 times in 2018, all on business trips, and I am happy with my stay every time.Courteous staff, spacious room, large and well-equipped gym, well spread buffet breakfast (the best I have seen), less than 5 minutes walk from Ebisu subway station, underpass connection to Yebisu garden tower, plenty of restaurants in the vicinity, complimentary shoe shine returned within the day....Price is on the high side but it is worth it!PS: Always request for non-smoking room. You can also request for yoga mat if needed.

Stayed two nights at the Westin Tokyo and loved the location and large, comfortable rooms with beautiful views of the city. The service was excellent, as was the breakfast buffet. Ebisu is a quiet neighborhood and the hotel is an easy walk to the subway station.
user_name:
djlnyc
New York City, New York

review_body: What more can I say to add to the tag line. No complaints. Very customer focused staff, many of whom spoke decent English or at least tried to. They were also smart to hire foreigners (aka those speaking English) in order better service their guests. Lovely gardens

If you want a fancy and perfect stay while you are in Tokyo, westin will be the perfect choice. Located in the middle of elite ebisu area and just 300-500 meter from ebisu garden and ebisu station. Service was top notch 5 stars accomodation with nice city view because im in 21th floor (spg member floor). Staff speaks English very well. Definitely big room since size really matter in Tokyo. But do not expect as big as mandarin hotel in Taipei.

I had one night at the Westin Tokyo in April.I live near by, so my review isn’t from tourist perspective.Taxi is recommended if you have luggage. From the nearest train station or bus stop, it’s still walking distance but but far.I applied suite night awards and they accepted it.The assigned room was spacious, clean, and was well maintained but old. There were nothing to complain but no luxury experience. Room was comfortable and was satisfied but no surprise.Staff at the executive lounge was amazing.They kept paying attention to all guests all the time. As a platinum member benefit I was able to get complimentary cocktails at the main bar which was one of great pros at this hotel.I had breakfast at the Victors. Unfortunately their service wasn’t as nice as I received in the lunch / dinner time.It maybe just short staffed but I had to wait long for evening, getting seat, tea, food ants etc. All in all this hotel is very good for the price and I recommend this hotel for family or solo traveler who see importance on their soft skills rather than hard.

The hotel has a high class European taste (kind of like the Langham London). The quality of service and attention to details with the staff are fantastic. Some rooms are not refurbished yet so it may need some facelift. But overall a great high quality hotel with solid service!

Maybe its just a side effect of the "new management" (a.k.a. Marriott acquisition), but the recognition of loyalty that I used to know and love at the Westin Tokyo has gone out the window. I have been deeply loyal to Westin Tokyo, spending many five-figure thousands of dollars on accommodation over a short period of time (i.e. spread out over no more than 2–3 years).However it seems staff care more about short term revenue (i.e. the one-off weddings and events) rather than recognising the repeat loyalty of existing customers.In the "old" Starwood days, I used to get good loyalty recognitions:- I used to get minor upgrades to better positioned rooms- Staff used to do their utmost to help achieve successful early-checkin instead of saying "sorry sir, come back for checkin at 1400"- Late checkout was always allowed until 1600. Now I'm told its 1400 and extension to 1600 will cost 50% of the full charge.It is unfortunate that my relationship with Westin Tokyo has had to come to an end in this way. However Westin Tokyo is not the only good hotel in Tokyo. I have no intention of ever staying at the Westin Tokyo again, the Westin Tokyo left me little choice in this decision, it makes me very sad, but what other choice do I have apart from "vote with my feet".It seems Westin Tokyo prefers to learn the hard way that it costs more to attract a new loyal customer than it does to do the small things to keep an existing loyal customer.

Located in Ebisu area, maybe not the first area appeared on your mind when you search for a hotel in Tokyo for a business trip. But as frequently stayed at the peak Ginza, Akasaka, Marunouchi, Kyobashi areas before, this time I stayed at The Westin Tokyo in order to find a more relaxed ambiance, and it was such a perfect stay!Very different with other Westin Hotels that more modern, this one as I believe one of the oldest Westin hotel in the world, it keeps it's elegance, warm and luxury hospitality. The room is spacious with the view of the city, grande lobby and restaurants.Located in the middle of residences area, gives more quite and serene feelings, however no worry for the access as walk away from the stations and taxi are everywhere.

just OK -actually somewhat disappointingRooms are good size but need a refreshGym small for this size of hotelExecutive lounge is small -to the point where they limit entry during dinner cocktails -seats were open but they were "reserved" -There is an alternative to the club (compass lounge) where you can get drinks and a fantastic view but no food and it is a smoking venueClub breakfast is adequate nice area - hotel restaurants are insanely expensive ($300 US PER PERSON) for a fullTappanaki meal- but there are many options a 2 minute walk awayTaxi is about Y10K from Haneda to hotel and Y 7.5K back - shuttle service is available but very limited

wdchuck1
New York City, New York

review_body: A very delayed review, but worth the share. Stayed there for a few days during our Japan trip. The hotel staff were helpful and fluent in english. The rooms are spacious and have all the necessities as well. The best part will probably be their convenience and close proximity to the Ebisu station. Would love to stay there again if have the opportunity! (:

Really has the feel of a JW or even a Ritz. Lounge nice with good breakfast. Gym is small but you can use the one down the street. Very friendly staff. Room is big by Tokyo standards ( really and big city standard). Truly enjoyed
user_name:
Ken H
Chester, New Jersey, United States

review_body: Stayed at Westin Tokyo twice recently. I liked the room being very spacious and very quiet neighborhood. There are good restaurants nearby. The Eibsu station is 15mins away from the hotel, if you don’t like walking, it may be a problem. And I would also say the service at Westin is just ok.By the way, Jiro won’t accept bookings from Westin.

The hotel room is very spacious and bright. The service is excellent. It is located in a very quiet and sort of artistic area with a 5-min walk you can reach Yebisu subway station. In less than 20 min you will be in downtown Tokyo.The breakfast is also pretty good too.

I stayed here twice within a week given our travel plans on Japan. I received the most outstanding service from Tomoko (I may have the name wrong). She was so accommodating upon our check in at the hotel. My friend unfortunately lost her wallet in Seoul, she helped us call AMEX to place a hold on the card. She even remember the issue when we came back and asked if there was anything she could do. She assisted my friend with calling ICN to locate the lost and found, amazing service! As a platinum SPG, we received the benefits of the breakfast and the lounge - definitely go to the top floor one time just for the views of Tokyo! Tomoko gave us a free drink at the top floor bar our very first night since we missed the happy hour. Overall fabulous hotel with great service!

This is a great classic hotel with impeccable service, nicely decorated and big rooms and excellent location. Ebisu is really nice area to stay given how close many Tokyo attractions are. It's also just across Ebisu garden complex where you can find many restaurants, mall and most importantly Yebisu beer hall :-) Kampai!

I stayed at the Tokyo Westin for business and i was very pleased with the staff and accommodations. The hotel is beautiful and the room was always clean and comfortable. The staff was extremely friendly and took care of all our needs. I booked a reservation through concierge and they were quick and informative. As for the room, the bathroom is nice and has both a tub and shower. I joined my colleague in the executive lounge in the 16th floor and they always had great breakfast and drinks in the afternoon. The staff was very friendly and caring. One of the girls made me an iced cappuccino to go every morning and it was fantastic! The hotel is also near to the Ebisu station which made it easy to travel daily to our meetings and nearby attractions and shopping. I truly enjoyed my stay and will recommend.

This seemed to me to be a bit off the beaten track, but since we were only there one night and I didn’t have much of a grasp of the logistics of the city, I could be completely wrong. Anyway, it was a short walk to a metro station so of course anything that could be reached by public transport wasn’t too far away.The hotel itself is very large and grand in a slightly dated kind of way. The foyer area, in particular, is very spacious. Customer service was, as you might expect, very good indeed, and the room was large and the beds comfortable. There didn’t seem to be much in the way of shopping nearby, although there was a Starbucks, a bakery and a pizza restaurant. This was a mainly residential area.

I stayed here for 5 nights in Sept. The staff at the hotel were fantastic. So accommodating and helpful. The guest rooms are spacious although a bit dated. They have about 5 restaurant options in the hotel. I didn't use them but did use room service which was great. The hotel is located only about 10 min from the train station which is so convenient. I took the train everywhere during my stay. They also offer a bus to Narita airport which was much less expensive than taking the train. You just need to book it 1 day ahead of time.

Location is great, train station near by so very convenient.Room: old and worn but clean and comfortableLounge: very nice view and snacks offered all day long Breakfast: very good with a lot of choiceStaff: very polite and professional

I booked this place very last minute and staff was quick to help arrange for my stay.I did not realise this is a 5 Star hotel until much later. Interior is a little dated but it is spacious and comfortable. Check in was quick and bags were brought up within 5 minutes. They have a gym too but it was closed on Sunday evening.I stayed on the 9th floor and the view is gorgeous!The hotel is a short walk to Ebisu Station. I was able to enjoy the walk to Shibuya in 35 mins. The location is so convenient and I will definitely choose this hotel again.

If you want to experience japanese charm, do not come to this hotel. If you are looking for a classy western style hotel this is a great pic. Spacious rooms, excellent breakfast buffet, cozy lounge. Customer service needs serious improvement. Upon arrival no king size bed available although I asked for me ..they were going to follow up , but I never heard back. As a Gold member, I was told I have to pay for the breakfast ..the next day they tell me it's free...strange.

My wife & I stayed at the Westin Hotel Tokyo for2nights（Friday & Saturday nights). They upgraded to a deluxe twin room with the Tokyo tower view for us by SPG service.夫婦2人で2泊しました。SPGメンバーシップで東京タワーが見られるツインルームにアップグレードしていただきました。■Location: AverageThe followings near by the hotel・Yebisu station ・The Yebisu beer place is nearby the hotel)・The Mitsukoshi department store・Garden park & Forest park.ロケーションとしては、恵比寿ビアプレイスや三越デパートが目の前にあり、その先には恵比寿駅あり。近くの庭園や森林公園があり、自然愛好者にも楽しめます。■Room：Enough for us (2people)■Bedding:Really comfort.　I had a perfect sleep by the Heavenly Bed!半信半疑でしたが、連夜、ヘブンリーベッドで快眠できました。■Bathroom: Good・Middle sized bathtub・Toilet with Washing unit・No water leak from a shower room海外でよく遭遇するシャワールームからの水漏れ無し。■Amenity:・Pod：Available・Coffee machine：Available・Minibar & Refrigerator:Available・Iron & table: Available・Hair Dryer: Available・TV: Large sized LCD (SONY)・DVD Player (Panasonic)・Toothbrush set, Shampoo, conditioner & body shampoo etc見ての通り、足りないものはないと言っても良いでしょう。■Staff: Kind & Polite  ■Restaurant:・Breakfast: Delicious & enough with Japanese, Western & Chinese dishes (buffet style)on the 1st floor. Avarage taste but few side dishes with Japanese dish  (mini buffet style)on the 2nd floor. Available on Sunday only.  We can not recommend the Japanese breakfast.・Dinner:Delicious French dinner corse at the restaurant "Victor's"(the 22nd floor)■Impressive happening:A staff dropped a coffee cup, so it broke & flew into piecesnext to our table. Once a manager ran to us, asked us "Are you all right?"He instructed briskly to his staffs after apologizing us.They completed their roles smoothly!朝食時に、隣のテーブルの後片付けをしていたスタッフがコーヒーカップを落とし、その破片が飛び散りました。そうすると、マネージャーが飛んできて、我々に「お怪我はありませんか？」と尋ねてくれました。そして、大丈夫と判ると、詫びてすぐにスタッフたちにきびきびと指示して、さっと片づけてしまいました。■Conclusion:Excellent for us　総合評価 我々には「素晴らしい」滞在でした。

The Westin could not have been nicer to SPG loyalists like us. One usually associates Westin’s with business but as tourists, they had all amenities . The top floor bar with its view of Tokyo was matchless & breakfast in the club lounge was great with attendants there to help you at every turn. The area of Ebisu is a quick metro ride to Tokyo Central with on Metro or by JR rail. Ebisu also has nice stores & restaurants on its own too. Westin Tokyo is a great choice if you want to get away from the hustle and frenzy of Ginza
user_name:
garye1953
New York City, New York

review_body: Probably a fantastic place in its heyday 1977 - this place is bad, really bad. TV doesn’t work, mid matched furniture is worn - The Westin Tokyo is ready for demolition. They allow smoking here - probably hoping that it will go down in flames. Aweful.

I stayed here as a solo traveller for two nights towards the end of my journey. Although I booked this hotel through hot rates, I wasn’t treated differently as everyone else. I thank the front desk supervisor who was very patient accommodating me with my request - facing city view. I thank the guest hostess who carried my luggage. She had the best smile! I thank the Aussie guest host at the lobby who was genuinely helpful when looking for directions or for help translating Japanese to English. The location is just across the Ebisu plaza and I had a good time there watching the festival and having some taste of the food truck meals. For family, biz traveller, solo traveller, and couples especially - this is a great location to stay as you don’t feel congested. As for the rooms - very spacious and very clean. Bed is very comfortable. I had the best sleep. I look forward to coming back soon!Thank you Westin Tokyo!

The Good: Great location, breakfast buffet is amazing, the people who work there are fantastic and always willing to help. Hotel is clean and well-maintained, everything works as expected.The So-So: Fitness Center is tiny, the weight room area is so small that only one person can really be in there at a time w/o feeling claustrophobic. The decor is really out of date and dark, I could never get my room light enough. The Bad: HARD bed - not Heavenly at all. To be fair, when I asked for a pad or something on the bed to make it softer, they complied quickly (see above for them always being willing to help), but it didn't help too much - back aches all week and I never get them from a bed. Bathroom Amenities - I literally had to leave a note to have the staff leave my shower soap, but for some reason they kept stacking washcloths in my room each day - I had about 12 in there when I checked out. DO NOT ORDER a beer in the lobby bar w/o first checking prices. I ordered a Guiness and it cost $25 USD!!! Utterly shocking. TV CHANNELS - there are very few English channels. With a long stay, there's not much to see on TV, don't count on it for much entertainment. And the worst part was the dry cleaning - I left a bag w/dry cleaning, but didn't call them to pick it up. So they picked it up anyway, then told me they were going to charge me a 50% upcharge because I didn't call. I politely declined their upcharge. Watch out for it.

I come to Tokyo regularly for business and stay at The Westin for weeks at a time. The staff overall are faultless but the manager of the Lobby Bar - Masashi Shibano - stands out amongst them all. He is the kindest, most attentive service person I have ever dealt with in all my travels. Please clone Masashi and send him to SPG hotels all around the world and everyone will be happy!

This was our first trip to Japan and we spent five nights at this very good hotel.This hotel is centrally located, which allowed easy planning to visit all the Tokyo tourist sites. The staff were helpful and provided very good service. I experienced the good service prior to the trip, as I spoke with the hotel and Club staff to plan our trip. Having stayed at many Westin hotels around the world, the Tokyo Westin is one of the best. Being Starwood platinum members, our two rooms were upgraded with good views and both rooms were given access to the Club lounge and breakfast at Victors.My family and I thought that the Club Lounge was very good. This included the Lounge's ambience, food presentations and most importantly Mr Hiro (manager) and his staff were all very good. The staff were friendly, helpful and provided great service.Although all of the Club Lounge staff were very good, we would like recognize Mon, one of the Lounge Assistants, she was excellent and provided outstanding service, including, a very nice surprise to celebrate our son's birthday.We would be happy to return to this hotel on any future visits to Tokyo.

Coming from Osaka there is a noticeable contrast. This is more business like and by looking at the customers at breakfast time you can clearly see more business then vacation travelers. They had your American breakfast as well as your Japanese breakfast. Getting a second cup of coffee can be challenging and seem to be rare in European an Asian countries. They do provide a good selection to prepare you for your day. We managed to receive an upgrade that made our vacation special. The room were clean and well kept, You get no complaint from me. The Ebisu area seemed new and a nice shopping area. We often went downstair in the department store for bento box and other delights. The Ebisu train station is nearby and is easy to use. Make sure you get a SUICA card if your traveling by subway/train. There is a tunnel below the hotel that will get you half way to the subway should you be in adverse weather.Tip: Make your lunch or dinner reservations are with the hotel concierge, some places will not take reservation unless its from a hotel.

This is a good hotel with friendly staff whose english level is well above average in japan. The hotel is also convenient in that it is quite near to a subway station and it is next to a modern shopping mall with a good choice of restaurants.

Before you leave to go Japan you must get a JR Pass for the rail network, you cannot buy it when you get there , it will save you a lot of money including travel on bullet train .Hotel is centrally located with underground station across the road also shopping centre.Executive lounge has continuous pastries coffee and refreshments all day.Cofffee Machine Tea , hair dryer supplied.Beautiful hotel .Wifi which is included is good.

We have a great stay at Westin hotel...the location is good even though it's not in the heart of Tokyo however it's very convenience to take subway to go around Tokyo, the Ebisu station just 5 minutes work from the hotel and next to hotel is a big department store and food store and many restaurants around the area..The rooms is spacious ( around 45sqm) compare with other 5 stars hotels in Tokyo, The reception staff was very kind to give me a corner room with nice view plus a. We surprise with full room amenities set up and they refill daily . There were also sets of yukata available in room for sleeping ..The service is great, before we arrived to Tokyo I sent email to Concierge to enquire for some tours information and airport transfer . Jun was very helpful and reponsed us very quick with detailed information which really help us to plan our trip efficiently. Thanks Jun so so much for your personalized serviceAfter our 1 day, I received phone call from family that my Grandmother passed away so I need to going hom as soonest as possible. At that time I was very shock and asked Ms. Chiaki from Concierge desk to help me change my flight so that I could be home for my Grandma's funeral. She sypathied me and quickly did her best to connect me to the airline and made sure that I could change my ticket . In the end I was able to change my flight and be home on time. I do appreciate for Chiaki's great assistance without her assistance on that day I really having a difficulty time to deal with the airlineOnce again we would like to thank you all and really look forward to be back again sometimes in Autumm or Spring next year.
user_name:
bhcindy
Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

review_body: I'm always a fan of Westin properties and have stayed at many Westin properties around the world. This one is no exception. The service is outstanding. My family of 5 were here in early July for 5 nights. I requested connecting rooms and that was taken care of. The staffs on the Executive Lounge were fantastic. They took care of us and my kids every morning at breakfast. The indoor walkway from hotel to Ebisu station were a saver during hot summer. It is about 5-7 minutes walk. The bell desk and concierge were very helpful whenever I needed help. They were able to arrange for my return to Narita airport using Limousine Bus. The cleaning crew did not take tips at all. We left tips in each of the two rooms (on top of the pillow) but they were still there when we got back. The only downside to this (and this is true for most of the hotels in Tokyo) is that there is no swimming pool. My kids obviously were not thrilled about it but they got over it quickly. All in all, we were very satisfied with our stay. Whenever we are back in Tokyo, we will definitely stay here again.

Stayed here many times and impressed each time with the excellent service and quality of the overall offering. Style and decor is classic European so not much Japanese feel which is a negative for me but it is very stylish. Rooms are spacious and modern. Good restaurant options and Compass Rose on top floor is a great bar to retreat to. Breakfast is excellent with a huge range. I had a Japanese breakfast on second floor restaurant looking onto a zen garden which was amazing. Location is excellent near Ebisu station and Yebisu Gardens for many food options. Gym is very small though, they could do better here.

We stayed 6 nights in room #912, a deluxe city room with a comfortable king bed.The room was the standard Westin type of hotel room with good amenities and excellent housekeeping. We had tea and coffee making facilities in the form of a filter coffee maker and a japanese water boiling device.Our room looked south (over to Meguro) and was quiet and spacious.The buffet breakfast was very enjoyable, with a great selection of western and japanese favourites. Service was always spot on and it was a pleasant way to start the day.We enjoyed drinks in both of the bars at the hotel. The bar on the top floor has a great view of Tokyo including Tokyo Tower, Shinjuku and Shibuya.We used the Limousine bus service to get between Narita airport and the hotel with no problem (transfer length was about 2 hours).Everyone at the hotel was exceptionally friendly and helpful.Wi-fi in the room was OK.We received complimentary bottled water each day.This was our third visit to Tokyo and our first venture into the Ebisu district. We were pleasantly surprised by the Meguro and Ebisu areas, the centres of which are about 10 minutes walk from the hotel. To get to Ebisu you can use the pedestrian walk way from the basement B1 level of the hotel to get all the way to Ebisu station (includes escalators a and travelators, totally undercover, useful in inclement weather). Both Ebisu and Meguro are on the Yamanote train line and also have other public transport options including the metro. There were no problems with getting taxis either.The area is much less touristy area than the areas where we've previously stayed in Tokyo which made for a very pleasant stay. We spent a bit of time exploring the excellent museums within a short walking distance from the hotel: TOP (Photographic art gallery), Teien Art Museum and garden, Yamatane Art Museum and Kyu Asakura House.We also walked to Meguro for dinner a couple of times (try Tonkatsu Tonki and Yoshicho Meguro). Ebisu is filled with lots of cute coffee shops, bars and eateries. Ebisu Yokocho is a fun food "lane" worth visiting. Ebisu Garden Place Complex has Mitsukoshi department store with a good supermarket (and food hall) in the basement.We would stay here again.

Located on hilltop in Ebisu - close to subway stop. Service is, of course, traditional Japanese perfection. The exec lounge serves decent breakfast and dinner snacks (top 25% rating based on my assessment of all lounges I've been to). View is nice. Rooms and decor is clean and has an Italian / greco-roman furnished look. There is also a small but very nice zen-garden with waterfall in the back of hotel.

Good location, not far from Shibuya, and Ebisu station, but overpriced for what you receive, you are required to pay for extras, example, sauna, spa, even if you have already paid for executive rooms. If you require a late check out they are not accommodating at all. Staff are in need of training. Consider other options before booking at the Westin Tokyo

The rooms are very spacious and the staff gave us a warm welcome. There is nothing touristy nearby and you have to walk 10 min to get to the subway station the good thing is that in the way there is a tunnel to help you get there.

This is hotel is conveniently located in a fancy neighbourhood not far from an area with lots bars and restaurants. For Tokyo, the room was very big with a large bathroom, it’s rare for Japan to have so much space in a hotel room. Room furniture style was old and fancy like french 18th century style. If you like modern room, this hotel is not for you. View from the room on Tokyo including the Tokyo Tower, very nice by night. Breakfast buffet was ok, nothing amazing about it.

History: Originally built and opened in 1994. Renovated in 2009.Location: In Meguro/Ebisu area of Tokyo. Approximately 10-15 minutes walk from Ebisu train station. Urban.Interior Décor: Westin standard. Sophisticated and luxurious. Excellently maintained. Well renovated to reflect modern travelers' needs such as extra electric outlets, USB ports and per room wireless internet connection.Exterior Appearance: 2 story building in upscale commercial/residential area.Outside view from the room I stayed at (1425): Obstructed panorama view of Meguro and Setagaya wards to west.Room Description: Luxurious and lush look. 1 king bed corner deluxe room, upgraded from 2 beds deluxe room. Attractive sets of bath amenities.Room Size: Approximately, 42 square meters. Comfortably spacious.Room Cleanness: Clean. Bathroom: Clean and good size. Large bathtub, shower booth.Noise Insulation: Excellent. Very peaceful.Price and Value: Luxurious setting.Breakfast: Terrace on the 1st floor. Very good all you can eat buffet featuring wide sets of Japanese and western food selections. Excellent Bed: Firm softness. Slept fine.Services: Professionally trained friendly hotel staffs.

I've stayed at this fantastic facility many times over the past 11 years. Even when I lived in Tokyo I had many of my guests stay here. All of us had amazing experience of this hotel be it staff, facilities, truly 5 star rooms and amenities and great connectivity of this hotel by taxi and train. I have no reason to consider any other hotel in Tokyo.

I picked this hotel with my family mainly because of the location. It's quiet and too far away from the main area of Tokyo. We enjoyed the walk through the park every night. We also loved the hotel. The rooms were very clean and the beds were very comfortable.The concieage was very helpful and welcoming. A great hotel should come with great services!

This was our last stay in Tokyo and I almost wish we'd stayed here the whole time!The hotel is a short(ish) walk from Ebisu station. There's plenty to do in the area and plenty of great places to eat a short walk from the hotel. Upon check-in we were immediately greeted by the friendly staff and the hotel has an amazing lobby area and a great bar with an extensive whiskey selection. We had a great view of the city from our floor and the bed was super comfortable (as you'd expect from the Westin). Upon check-out we messed up the airport bus times. The staff went above and beyond to help us get on the airport bus on time with all our stuff (we have a little toddler so we had a bit of luggage!).The hotel has a Westin Workout gym, which was fine for a workout (although it's limited on weight equipment) and has a number of treadmills that face out the window towards Yebisu garden.I really can't fault this hotel, and look forward to staying at this hotel again next time I am in Tokyo.

I have stayed multiple times at this hotel earlier, but this time around I had a unsavoury experience. Since Tokyo is one of the safest places on earth and Housekeeping is normally diligent, I do leave my ipad, etc in the room for charging when I am out as normal practice. On this occasion, I left my ipad in the room when I had stepped out for work and returned after 12 hours, I realised that the screen was broken. Since I had used the ipad in the morning, I am quite sure that the incident had occured during my absence the room. No doubt whatsoever on this point. Upon reporting the issue, I was contacted by the Duty Manager with detailed report of who entered the room for various activities including Fire Alarm check, House keeping, Supervisor, etc. Bottom line, he said that he has checked with his employees and all of them said that none had touched my ipad. It is logical to have his point as counter if there was 1 staff member; when there are 4-5 entries and exits, in my view he should have seen that scope for ambiguity in staff statements do exist. It is staff word against mine and as per Duty Manager, he believes his staff which is simple insinuation that I am lying.This is not withstanding the fact that I am an SPG Plat who has spent 50+ nights in this hotel in last 18-24 months. I understand accidents can happen but this rigid attitude of sticking to their position on this topic and no effort in service recovery simply doesn’t make the cut. I think on this aspect, they were quite sub par. Note for all and to myself in particular, regardless of however safe location, one needs to follow the basic rules of keeping things safe. Else such incidents act as rude reminders!

I have stayed at Westin resorts before and the service and quality of the hotel meets the Westin service .While the hotel is a bit out of this way from the Tokyo financial capital - it’s s reasonable taxi fare or train ride . The ebisu station is a bit of walk but not too bad as there are walkways - that minimize the drag on feet . The service staff was very helpful - I was greeted upon the exit from taxi - and I was surprised that they remembered me - even after being there a while ago . I love the lounge on 17th floor - great place to relax - breakfast, day snacks and evening snacks are plentiful.While a bit expensive relative to other hotels - I like the totality of service, food and room comfort .

We had reviewed various descriptions of the Westin Tokyo before we made our reservation. Most of the reviews we saw were extremely positive. The few negative ones had to do with the distance from the subway and the point that it was an old hotel that was renovated. Let me assure you the hotel does not look or feel old at all! It’s gorgeous. And as far as distance from the subway, there is a walking escalator so its not as if you’re feet get tired. And its only 7 minutes. The nearby complex that one has to walk through offer SO much that its worth it. I have to compliment the hotel on the quality, the ambience, and the level of personalized service. The rooms are exceptionally clean. The amenities are wonderful. Everything is quiet and peaceful, yet highly efficient. The service throughout our stay was fantastic. We loved the buffet breakfast and its varied choices, as well as the coffee shop and its delicacies. Above all, there is one person whom we would like to point out as truly representing the spirit of the hotel. Mr. Masanori Mano is an exceptional individual and a credit to the Westin family. We found him to be most courteous and friendly, yet extremely efficient and thoughtful. He was wonderful to deal with. He will go out of his way to make your stay comfortable. There are others who also deserve mention - at the front desk, the concierge desk and at room maintenance, but Mr Mano stood out.I believe you will love the Westin Tokyo.

The Westin is always impressive. We really enjoyed our visit. The location is central and easy to access. The restaurants served great food and the staff was very helpful. The rooms were a little smaller, but very nice overall.

The Westin Tokyo is definitely not a cheap hotel even by Tokyo standards - but it is located across the street from Ebisu garden place which is full of shopping and great restaurants. It's a short taxi ride to the station as well (~10 min) as there's no shuttle but not too difficult to get to. From an exterior standpoint, the hotel is pretty bland and blends into the skyline - however, the views from the rooms are nice especially on the higher floors. There's not many large buildings around it so you really get some great views of the Tokyo landscape. The front desk staff is quick, efficienty and friendly - they were able to check my guest into my room without me and were even able to upgrade us to a suite. Always appreciate it when hotels know how to treat their customers right.The room itself was very well appointed - comfortable and spacious with great views of the city. The bed was very comfortable (as most Westin's are) and the nespresso machine in the room is a nice touch (compared to the lame coffee you get in US Westin's). The club lounge is standard asian style - which is to say much nicer than the US. Breakfast had a wide selection, dinner hors d'orveus were decent, and they had a great liquor selection.Last thing of note, the bellmen were falling over each other to help us out... definitely very well appreciated. However, the concierge was very cold and unhelpful - I stood there for 5 minutes before she would pay me any attention as she was busy shuffling papers. Not what I consider acceptable for a luxury hotel at that price point, especially for someone like me who has traveled over the world with SPG (average 200 nights a year). Only reason it's a 4 star review instead of 5.

I recently started rating my hotel experiences and after leaving two negative reviews I had to reflect on my stays and question whether I was just being too harsh. It took me about a minute to realize, no I have had absolutely great stays with the most recent being my fantastic time at the Westin Tokyo! The hotel itself is beautiful as are the grounds around it. We stayed in a suite with a walk in shower, massive tub, and the very cool bidet set up that Japan is known for. The decor is a bit dated, but kept in immaculate condition and still with its charm. The location was great, walkable, not overly commercial but not too out of the way. This was my first trip to Japan so I was very happy to find that everywhere we were interested in going was easily accessible through the local subway line. The bar upstairs in the hotel served a tasty cocktail in a trendy but not too loud or overdone atmosphere. The breakfast buffet had everything you could want from ramen, salad bar and sushi to the traditional bagels, omelets your way and an assortment of fresh juices.I didn't have much need to address the staff but any time I did everyone was hugely accommodating, polite and knowledgeable.Overall a really great experience and I would recommend it to anyone, particularly anyone a little wary of their first time to Japan and hoping for a bit of the comforts of the west.

I seldom write a review while I am still in the hotel, but this property deserves it. First of all it’s beautiful, from the moment you walk in, you know you are in a very special place. The executive lounge and its staff are truly exceptional, friendly, attentive, and professional. The food is varied and should suit any palate. They informed me that the room we were in might get noisy and moved us to a suite, we didn’t ask , they just did it. The room we were in was absolutely fine, and had the best shower of anyplace I have stayed. It may be a little expensive for some, but it’s really worth it.

The staff was awesome; the facilities were super clean; the service was terrific; the food was delicious! No complaints here; truly the Westin made my stay in Tokyo comfortable. Any time I return to Tokyo, I’ll be staying there without thinking twice about it!

A truly coming home, constant high level service over many many years. Food is also always the best of the best as is the service.Only minus is the fact that smoking is still allowed in the bar, a pity when enjoying the excellent food or wine...

Not quite as convenient or luxurious as the Prince Gallery Kioicho, but still a very nice property. I checked in after a long transpacific flight flawlessly and a category upgrade for my Platinum status was honored without having to ask for it. The room was well appointed, if slightly dated. The spa and work out room was well appointed and the club level lounge sported awesome views of Tokyo and the service impeccable. I love traveling in Japan as it is cultured above and beyond anything one can expect in the US. One note for folks that stay here, there is no subway line nearby without a 20 minute walk through alleys and residential areas, also you have to walk along a busy freeway to get to the hotel. However, the hotel grounds are luxurious and quiet.

I would highly recommend The Westin Tokyo. Our room was big and comfortable. We are 5 star in SPG, so we also received access to the club lounge. The food and drinks were great and the staff was very nice. The hotel is within easy walking distance to the Ebisu train station (you can walk underground directly from the hotel, if you find the right door, so just ask, it’s not the easiest to find). We’ll definitely stay here again!

Stayed at the Westin for a week in February. Their concierge were excellent in getting reservations at popular and exclusive restaurants for us. The room was immaculate, with a great view of Mt. Fuji on clear days. Very convenient location for using transit to get around the city.

Good size room and beautifully decorated bathroom with separate shower and tub. Cleaning service was immaculate. Service was professional and courteous throughout the hotel. Lounge access included Happy Hour, which included sparkling wine and other alcohol plus a selection of food that you could easily fill up on. The food was generous and delicious. Though it was more suited for westerners who were homesick for western food than what I wanted to eat in Japan (cold cuts, seafood soup, rice and chicken, but no sashimi, sushi, noodles, or potstickers). Another reviewer mentioned udon to order, but I didn't know about this. They also had a good selection of desserts. Honestly, the selection at the lounge here was fantastic; larger than those offered at Westin's in the U.S.Location of the hotel is further away from the 'most often toured' places of Tokyo, but it is right next to a shopping complex full of restaurants, shops, and convenience stores. You could get there from the underground connection without having to go out into the sun. I wish I had more time to explore the shopping complex and restaurants. Extra thanks to the Australian employee (sorry I forgot his name) who went out of his way to give us directions and advice on a Japanese train app. Everyone was truly helpful.

We spent a delightful weekend in a beautiful room on the Executive Floor of the hotel. Our breakfasts (at Victor's and in the Executive lounge) were delicious, and we greatly enjoyed evenings at the Compass Bar on the top floor and a relaxing morning in the marvellous spa as well. The hotel staff were uniformly pleasant, polite, and professional, attending to our needs with care and efficiency.

We have stayed at this hotel a number of times now and every time it seems a little better.We were on the 18th floor in an executive room and from the enormous window in our room we could see Mt Fuji in the distance, fantastic.Situated in the quiet suburb of Ebisu, the area is quite beautiful. Across the road on the way to the metro is a great department store, fantastic gardens and lots of places to eat and drinkThe staff were very courteous and very helpful in every way, we had no bad experience at all, very lovely hotel, I can recommend completely. Also very helpful and efficient when we sent our luggage on to Kyoto ahead of us, that is a fabulous service that everyone should take advantage of when travelling in Japan.

The classic modern European decor Westin Tokyo Hotel is located in the quiet upscale neighborhood of Ebisu in central Tokyo. The hotel's design is modern and has beautiful rooms and suites.The hotel is connected via an underground passage to the Yebisu Garden Place, a shopping and dining complex, and Ebisu Station.Located in a trendy neighborhood of Shibuya Ward is Tokyo Metro’s Ebisu Station, which is serviced by the Hibiya Line. Ebisu is the eponymous mythological god of luck, fishermen and merchants. His statue next to the station is an common meeting point. The station was once home to an adjacent Yebisu brewery. Nowadays, beer lovers can take a short walk to the Yebisu Beer Museum via Exit 1 of the Metro.

It is away from Tokyo center but only one stop from Shibuya and 30-45 min on the subway to other major attractions in Tokyo (Tsukiji Market, Tokyo Tower, Imperial Palace, Edo Tokyo Museum, Akihabara, etc.) - From Ebius station, you could walk via the People walk and at the exit, you will walk thru Ebisu square to get to the hotel. If you have large luggage and multiple, best to take a taxi as you exit Ebisu or straight from Shibuya station. Not expensive.- The hotel is very nice, clean and large room. We chose the corner room with a great view over moving 2~3x if we want a suite.- Staffs are wonderful, friendly, especially the lounge staffs!! Thank you for great hospitality, friendly service and always with a beautiful smiles!! - Excellent foods, love the breakfast buffet varieties, hot, made to order Udon, eggs, Japanese complete set of breakfast, fresh fruits and juice!!- Recommend waking up early and start breakfast at 6:45am or 7am to avoid the crowds. Get your exercise in at 5:45-6:45am. :)- Due to it's location, it is quiet and next to Ebisu square which is great! There are restaurants, Starbucks and small mall and seats to relax and watch people... :)- There are several museums and parks near by to visit also (Yebisu, same as Saboro, Metropolitan of Art, etc.)Nearby Ebisu station, you could find a Shake Shack burger, which was a surprise to us and NICE since we do miss a good burger from home. Too much sashimi and udon in 2 weeks span. :)

Westin Tokyo with European style. Early Check in and got the room. The room size is big and comfortable The location is peaceful and quiet. If you want to go to train station like subway and carry heavy luggage you have to walk through the mall but I’ve enjoyed it :) If you want to go to airport there is also limousine bus and surprisingly from the lobby hotel. It cost me around 3100yen (this is my favourite part). You can ask the concierge to arrange one night before . Love Westin Tokyo

WOW... wow, wow, wow...There isn't anything I did not enjoy from The Westin Tokyo. We stayed on the top floor suite and it was marvelous. The view was pretty good and the breakfast was delicious. The team members made everything feel as if we were home. The check-in was fast and we were able to be on our way quickly to enjoy dinner the same night we arrived. If you can stay in this hotel, do it! There isn't a single reason I can provide that would state otherwise. The hotel is a bit far from the main attractions, but it's just a train or cab away. If you do stay here, it will take about 8-10min to get to the JR (metro) lines to go into DT. I believe this is the upscale side of Tokyo as all the nice cars, malls and even the metro was beyond outstanding and while you are walking to the metro station, you'll have some amazing views of some gardens that look fantastic for your IG. LOL.

Location is great. The Ebisu train station is like 12 minutes walk away. It’s a very convenient location - 30 minutes from Haneda International airport; 1 train stop away or 25 min walk from my office in Meguro train station; 1 stop away from Shibuya. The location is a huge plus. Surroundings - it’s near the Yebisu beer museum. Love it since I enjoy beer. Must go try their stout beer, it’s really nice. Quite a cool museum. The hotel itself -Room is spacious and comfortable. A little old but clean. I requested for a room nearer to the lift lobby so my room is like a corner room. Toilet has all the toiletries I need and there is complimentary bath salt which I used in the bath tub. In room dinning is great. Limited options but service is good and arrive promptly. I tried their international breakfast buffet for a day and it’s a good spread - mixture of western and Japanese choices. Japanese choices are a little limited but it’s decent. Hospitality in japan is usually outstanding, however, I find their staff can be rigid. I had an incident where I’m checking out on a Sunday to go somewhere else for a night before flying back. I’ve requested to store my luggage in the hotel and I will return on Monday to pick it up. I requested for the hotel staff to book a restaurant outside of the hotel for me on Monday afternoon. He is not able to do it because I’m no longer their guest. Is it normal? Japanese culture is so different that I can never be sure anymore. Anyway, I do not want to press it. Having said that, while I was staying in the hotel, I requested for a reservation at a restaurant, they were able to accommodate my request. Hence it is not a negative point if you know what I mean. Many nice and small eateries around and outside the hotel. There is this skewers place which is like 5 minutes walk away towards the Ebisu train station which is a worthwhile visit. I see a few older Japanese men there so I thought this place must be authentic and it exceeded my expectations. I wish I had a chance to visit that small eatery again. I cannot read the name but it’s below the indian curry restaurant. Refer to the two photos for that small eatery.

The hotel is a standard great Westin with extra Japanese service thrown in. It's especially nice if you are a Starwood elite member.
